docs.title: Welcome to Nodo
docs.text: Nodo is a procedural 3D modeling application built on node-based workflows. Create complex geometry through visual programming - no coding required.

docs.title: What is Nodo?
docs.text: Nodo lets you create 3D models by connecting nodes in a graph. Each node performs an operation (create a sphere, transform geometry, combine shapes), and the connections define the workflow.

docs.title: Why Node-Based Modeling?
docs.text:
• Non-Destructive - Change any parameter at any time
  • Procedural - Models update automatically when you adjust inputs
  • Flexible - Infinite combinations of nodes and operations
  • Expression-Driven - Use math to drive parameters dynamically

docs.text:
Organized into 8 categories:

  • Generators (6) - Create primitives (Sphere, Box, Cylinder, Torus, Grid, Line)
  • Modifiers (5) - Extrude, Subdivide, Smooth, Noise Displacement, Bevel (basic)

  • Groups (7) - Group Create, Blast, Sort, Group Promote/Combine/Expand/Transfer
  • Deformers (3) - Bend, Twist, Lattice
  • Utilities (5) - Switch, Null, Output, File (import), Export

docs.text:
Every parameter supports mathematical expressions and references:

$radius * 2 + 1

// Trigonometry & functions

// Reference other nodes
ch("../Sphere/radius") * 2

// Reference graph parameters
$master_scale * 1.5

docs.title: Attributes
docs.text: Attributes are data attached to your geometry. They're the secret to data-driven procedural modeling - enabling selections, coloring, and advanced workflows.

docs.title: What are Attributes?
docs.text:
Attributes store information on geometry components:

Vertex (Point)  → Point Attributes   (position, color, normal, ...)
Face (Triangle) → Face Attributes    (material ID, ...)
Mesh (Object)   → Primitive Attribs  (name, layer, ...)

Think of them as spreadsheet data attached to your 3D geometry.

docs.title: Built-in Attributes
docs.text: Nodo automatically creates some attributes:

docs.title: Point Attributes
Face Attributes
docs.text: Name Type Description materialid int Material assignment N vector3 Face normal

docs.title: Primitive Attributes
docs.text: Name Type Description name string Object name

docs.title: Creating Attributes
docs.text: Use the Attribute Create node to add custom attributes.

docs.title: Example: Height Attribute
docs.text:
Goal: Store Y-position for each vertex

Setup: 

Sphere
  ↓
Attribute Create
  - Name: "height"
  - Type: Float
  - Value: @P.y

Result: Each vertex has a height attribute = its Y coordinate

Use: - Select high vertices: @height > 0.5 - Color by height: @Cd = [@height, 0, 0]

docs.title: Float
docs.text:
Single decimal number: 

@height = 1.5
@temperature = 37.2
@weight = 0.8

docs.title: Int
docs.text:
Whole number: 

@id = 42
@material = 3
@group_id = 1

docs.title: Vector2
docs.text:
Two floats (UV coordinates): 

@uv = [0.5, 0.75]

docs.title: Vector3
docs.text:
Three floats (positions, colors, normals): 

@P = [1.0, 2.0, 3.0]
@Cd = [1.0, 0.0, 0.0]  # Red
@N = [0.0, 1.0, 0.0]   # Up

docs.title: String
docs.text:
Text: 

@name = "pillar_base"
@material_name = "brick"

docs.title: 1. Selection (Groups)
docs.text:
Select geometry based on attribute values:

Group Node:
- Mode: Expression
- Expression: @P.y > 0.5

Result: Select all vertices above Y=0.5

docs.title: 2. Color
docs.text:
Set vertex colors procedurally:

Attribute Create:
- Name: Cd
- Type: Vector3
- Value: [@P.x, @P.y, 0]

Result: Color based on position (red = X, green = Y)

docs.title: 3. Conditional Operations
docs.text:
Use attributes to drive operations:

Delete faces where @materialid == 2
Extrude faces where @selected == 1

docs.title: 4. Data-Driven Deformations
docs.text:
Example: Twist based on height

Attribute Create:
- Name: twist_amount
- Value: @P.y * 45

Then in Twist node:
- Angle: ch("@twist_amount")

docs.title: Color Gradient by Height
docs.text:
1. Sphere
2. Attribute Create:
   Name: Cd
   Type: Vector3
   Value: [0, @P.y + 0.5, 0]

Result: Green gradient (dark bottom, bright top)

docs.title: Random Colors
docs.text:
1. Box
2. Attribute Create:
   Name: Cd
   Type: Vector3
   Value: [rand(@id), rand(@id+1), rand(@id+2)]

Result: Each vertex has random color

docs.title: Material ID by Position
docs.text:
1. Cylinder
2. Attribute Create:
   Name: materialid
   Type: Int
   Value: @P.y > 0 ? 1 : 2

Result: Top half = material 1, bottom = material 2

docs.title: Distance from Center
docs.text:
1. Grid
2. Attribute Create:
   Name: dist
   Type: Float
   Value: length(@P)

Result: Each point stores distance from origin

docs.title: Attribute Interpolation
docs.text: When geometry changes, attributes can be interpolated:

docs.title: Subdivide
docs.text:
Vertex A: @height = 0.0
Vertex B: @height = 1.0

After subdivide:
New vertex (midpoint): @height = 0.5 (interpolated)

Attributes blend smoothly across new geometry.

docs.title: Merge
docs.text:
Mesh A vertices: @id = 0, 1, 2, ...
Mesh B vertices: @id = 0, 1, 2, ...

After merge:
Combined: @id renumbered to avoid conflicts

docs.title: Attribute Promotion
docs.text: Convert between attribute classes:

docs.title: Point → Face
docs.text:
Average point values for each face:

3 vertices with @height = [0.5, 0.6, 0.7]
Face @height = (0.5 + 0.6 + 0.7) / 3 = 0.6

docs.title: Face → Point
docs.text:
Distribute face values to points:

Face @material = 2
All 3 vertices get @material = 2

Use Case: Material IDs, selections

docs.title: Deleting Attributes
docs.text:
Use Attribute Delete node to remove unneeded attributes:

Attribute Delete:
- Name: "temp_*"  (wildcard pattern)
- or specific: "old_color", "scratch_data"

Why delete? - Reduce memory usage - Clean up temporary data - Prepare for export

docs.title: Reading Attributes
docs.text:
@P.y               # Current point's Y position
@Cd.r              # Red component of color
@N                 # Normal vector
@id                # Vertex ID

docs.title: Writing Attributes
docs.text:
@Cd = [1, 0, 0]           # Set red
@height = @P.y * 2        # Double Y position
@active = @P.y > 0 ? 1 : 0  # Boolean flag

docs.title: Math on Attributes
docs.text:
@dist = length(@P)               # Distance from origin
@normalized_height = @P.y / 10   # Normalize
@sum = @val1 + @val2             # Combine values

docs.title: Conditionals
docs.text:
@result = @value > 0.5 ? 1 : 0
@color = @hot ? [1,0,0] : [0,0,1]  # Red if hot, blue if cold

docs.title: Checkerboard Pattern
docs.text:
Attribute Create:
- Name: checker
- Value: (floor(@P.x) + floor(@P.z)) % 2
- Then use for color:
  @Cd = @checker == 0 ? [1,1,1] : [0,0,0]

docs.title: Radial Gradient
docs.text:
Attribute Create:
- Name: radial
- Value: length([@ P.x, @P.z])
- Then:
  @Cd = [1 - @radial, @radial, 0]

docs.title: Selection Mask
docs.text:
Attribute Create:
- Name: mask
- Value: sin(@P.x * 3.14) > 0 ? 1 : 0

Group (Expression): @mask == 1
Group Delete: Removes masked areas

docs.title: Instance ID
docs.text:
After Copy to Points:
Each instance gets @instanceid

Use for variation:
@Cd = [@instanceid * 0.1, 0, 0]

docs.title: Point Attributes
docs.text:
• Stored per vertex
  • Most common type
  • Used for: positions, colors, normals, UVs

Example: 

1000 vertex mesh
@Cd attribute = 1000 color values (one per vertex)

docs.title: Face Attributes
docs.text:
• Stored per triangle
  • Less common
  • Used for: material IDs, face selections

Example: 

500 triangle mesh
@materialid = 500 integer values (one per face)

docs.title: Vertex Attributes
docs.text:
• Same as point attributes in Nodo
  • Terminology varies by software

docs.title: 1. Name Attributes Clearly
docs.text:
✅ @selection_mask, @height_normalized, @color_gradient
❌ @x, @temp, @thing

docs.title: 2. Clean Up Temporary Attributes
docs.text:
After using @temp_dist for calculation:
→ Attribute Delete: temp_*

docs.title: 3. Use Standard Names
docs.text:
Follow conventions: 

@Cd   for color (not @color, @rgb)
@N    for normal (not @norm)
@uv   for texture coords

docs.title: 4. Check Attribute Type
docs.text:
Float: Single values (height, weight, temperature)
Vector3: Positions, colors, normals
Int: IDs, indices, material numbers

docs.title: 5. Scope Awareness
docs.text:
Point attributes: Per-vertex data (most common)
Face attributes: Per-triangle data (materials, selections)

docs.title: Attribute Not Found
docs.text:
Error: @myattr doesn't exist

Fix: - Check spelling (case-sensitive!) - Verify Attribute Create node executed - Check attribute was created on points (not faces)

docs.title: Wrong Data Type
docs.text:
Error: Assigning vector to float attribute

Fix: - Match types: Float = scalar, Vector3 = [x,y,z] - Convert if needed: length(@P) (vector → float)

docs.title: Attribute Not Updating
docs.text:
Cause: Node not re-executing

Fix: - Change a parameter to force update - Check node connections - Verify expression mode enabled

docs.title: Colors Not Showing
docs.text:
Cause: @Cd attribute missing or wrong range

Fix: - Ensure @Cd is Vector3 - Values must be 0.0 to 1.0 range - Enable vertex colors in viewport

docs.title: Minimize Attributes
docs.text:
Only create what you need: 

❌ 20 temporary attributes
✅ 3 essential attributes + delete temps

docs.title: Batch Operations
docs.text:
✅ One Attribute Create with multiple attributes
❌ 10 separate Attribute Create nodes

docs.title: Optimize Expressions
docs.text:
✅ @dist = length(@P)  (calculated once)
❌ Multiple uses of length(@P)  (calculated each time)

docs.title: Rainbow Colors
docs.text:
Grid (10×10)
  ↓
Attribute Create:
  Name: Cd
  Type: Vector3
  Value: [(sin(@id * 0.5) + 1) * 0.5,
          (cos(@id * 0.3) + 1) * 0.5,
          (sin(@id * 0.7) + 1) * 0.5]

docs.title: Height-Based Selection
docs.text:
Cylinder
  ↓
Group:
  Mode: Expression
  Expression: @P.y > 0.5
  ↓
Group Delete (delete selected = top half removed)

docs.title: Distance Falloff
docs.text:
Sphere
  ↓
Attribute Create:
  Name: falloff
  Value: 1.0 - min(length(@P) / 2.0, 1.0)
  ↓
Attribute Create:
  Name: Cd
  Value: [@falloff, @falloff, @falloff]

Result: White center, black edges

docs.title: Geometry Types
docs.text: Understanding how 3D geometry is represented in Nodo helps you make better procedural models and use nodes effectively.

docs.title: Mesh Structure
docs.text: Nodo works with triangle meshes - the most common 3D geometry representation.

docs.title: Basic Components
docs.text:
Vertex (Point)
    ↓
Edge (Line between 2 vertices)
    ↓
Face (Triangle from 3 vertices)
    ↓
Mesh (Collection of connected faces)

docs.title: What are Vertices?
docs.text:
Vertices (singular: vertex) are points in 3D space with (x, y, z) coordinates.

Vertex = (x, y, z)

Example:
v1 = (0.0, 0.0, 0.0)   # Origin
v2 = (1.0, 0.0, 0.0)   # 1 unit on X axis
v3 = (0.0, 1.0, 0.0)   # 1 unit on Y axis

docs.title: Vertex Attributes
docs.text:
Vertices can store additional data:

  • Position (required): x, y, z coordinates
  • Normal: Direction for smooth shading
  • Color: RGB or RGBA values
  • UV: Texture coordinates
  • Custom: Any data you define

Access in expressions: 

@P       # Position vector (x, y, z)
@P.x     # X coordinate
@P.y     # Y coordinate
@P.z     # Z coordinate
@N       # Normal vector
@Cd      # Color

docs.title: What are Edges?
docs.text:
Edges connect two vertices, forming the "skeleton" of your mesh.

Edge = (vertex_index_1, vertex_index_2)

Example:
e1 = (0, 1)   # Edge from vertex 0 to vertex 1
e2 = (1, 2)   # Edge from vertex 1 to vertex 2

docs.title: Edge Uses
docs.text:
• Wireframe rendering - Show mesh structure
  • Smoothing - Define hard/soft edges
  • Selections - Select edge loops for operations
  • Beveling - Round off corners

docs.title: What are Faces?
docs.text:
Faces are flat surfaces defined by 3 or more vertices. In Nodo (via Manifold), all faces are triangles.

Triangle Face = (v1, v2, v3)

Example:
f1 = (0, 1, 2)   # Triangle using vertices 0, 1, 2

docs.title: Triangle vs Quad
docs.text:
Traditional modeling: Often uses quads (4-vertex faces)

Nodo approach: Everything is triangles internally - Simpler math - Guaranteed planar - Better for boolean operations - Game/render engines use triangles anyway

Note: Some display modes may show quads visually, but they're pairs of triangles.

docs.title: Face Normals
docs.text:
Each face has a normal - a vector pointing "outward" from the surface:

     ↑ Normal
     |
   ╱─┴─╲
  ╱     ╲    Triangle face
 ╱       ╲
╱─────────╲

Determines: - Which side is "front" (visible) - Lighting calculations - Backface culling

Right-hand rule: Vertices in counter-clockwise order → normal points toward you

docs.title: 1. Manifold Mesh
docs.text:
Definition: A "watertight" mesh with no holes, proper edges, valid topology.

Properties: - Every edge connects exactly 2 faces - No isolated vertices - No duplicate faces - Defines a closed volume

Why it matters: - Required for boolean operations - Defines inside/outside - Can calculate volume

Nodo uses Manifold library for robust boolean operations - prefers manifold meshes.

docs.title: 2. Non-Manifold Mesh
docs.text:
Definition: Mesh with topological issues.

Common problems: - Holes or gaps - Edges with 1 or 3+ faces - Isolated vertices or faces - Overlapping geometry

Results: - Booleans may fail - Normals may flip - Rendering artifacts

Fix: - Check geometry carefully - Use Merge node (can weld vertices) - Ensure generators create clean topology

docs.title: 3. Boundary Mesh
docs.text:
Definition: Mesh with open edges (not closed).

Example: 

Plane - has boundary (4 open edges)
Sphere - no boundary (fully closed)

Use: - Planes, grids (intentionally open) - Partial geometry - Not ideal for booleans

docs.title: Geometry Attributes
docs.text: Attributes store data on vertices, faces, or edges.

docs.title: Point (Vertex) Attributes
docs.text:
Stored per-vertex:

P        Position (x, y, z)
N        Normal vector
Cd       Color (r, g, b)
uv       UV coordinates
id       Vertex ID
[custom] Any data you create

Access: 

@P.y > 0.5    # Select vertices above Y=0.5
@Cd = [1,0,0] # Set color to red

docs.title: Face Attributes
docs.text:
Stored per-triangle:

materialid   Material assignment
N            Face normal
[custom]     Any face data

Use: - Material IDs for multi-material objects - Face selections - Data-driven face operations

docs.title: Primitive Attributes
docs.text:
Stored per-primitive (mesh/object):

name         Object name
layer        Layer assignment
[custom]     Object-level data

docs.title: Local vs World Space
docs.text:
Local (Object) Space: - Origin at object's pivot - Coordinates relative to object - What you see in node parameters

World Space: - Global coordinate system - Absolute positions in scene - Used for final placement

Example: 

Box at (0,0,0) local, but object moved to (5,5,5) world
Vertex (1,0,0) local = (6,5,5) world

docs.title: Transform Affects Space
docs.text:
Transform node changes object's world position:

Sphere (local 0,0,0)
  ↓ Transform: Translate (5,0,0)
Sphere (world 5,0,0)

But vertex local coords unchanged!

docs.title: Geometry
docs.text:
What it is: The actual shape - vertex positions, face shapes

Changes: - Move vertices - Scale object - Deform mesh

Example: 

Before: Cube 1x1x1
After:  Cube 2x2x2 (same topology, different geometry)

docs.title: Topology
docs.text:
What it is: The connectivity - how vertices connect to form faces

Changes: - Add/remove faces - Subdivide - Boolean operations - Merge vertices

Example: 

Before: Cube with 8 vertices, 12 faces
After:  Subdivided cube with 26 vertices, 48 faces (different topology)

Key Point: Some operations change topology, some only geometry.

docs.title: Adding Geometry
docs.text: Nodes that create: - Sphere, Box, Cylinder → Generate new meshes - Grid, Line → Create planar/linear geometry

docs.title: Modifying Geometry
docs.text: Nodes that change shape (topology unchanged): - Transform - Move/rotate/scale - Bend, Twist - Deform - Smooth (some modes) - Relax positions

docs.title: Modifying Topology
docs.text: Nodes that change connectivity: - Subdivide - Add faces - Extrude - Extend faces - Boolean - Cut/combine meshes - Group Delete - Remove faces

docs.title: Combining Geometry
docs.text: Nodes that merge: - Merge - Combine meshes (optional welding) - Boolean Union - Merge with CSG - Array - Create copies

docs.title: What are Normals?
docs.text:
Normals are vectors indicating surface direction.

     ↑ Vertex Normal
     |
   ╱─┴─╲
  ╱     ╲
 ╱   →   ╲  Face Normal
╱─────────╲

docs.title: Face Normals
docs.text:
• Perpendicular to triangle surface
  • Automatic from vertex order
  • Used for backface culling

docs.title: Vertex Normals
docs.text:
• Averaged from adjacent face normals
  • Used for smooth shading
  • Can be manually set for hard edges

docs.title: Smooth vs Flat Shading
docs.text:
Flat Shading: - Uses face normals only - Faceted appearance - Good for hard-surface models

Smooth Shading: - Interpolates vertex normals - Rounded appearance - Good for organic shapes

In Nodo: - Smooth node can recalculate normals - Display settings control shading mode

docs.title: What are UVs?
docs.text:
UV coordinates map 3D surface to 2D texture space.

3D Mesh        2D Texture
   ↓               ↓
 Vertex        UV Coord
(x,y,z)   →    (u,v)

Range: Usually 0.0 to 1.0 in U and V

Use: - Apply images as textures - Material mapping - Procedural patterns

In Nodo: - Some generators create UVs automatically - UV unwrapping (advanced feature, future)

docs.title: Winding Order
docs.text:
Vertex order determines face direction:

Counter-Clockwise (CCW) = Front face
Clockwise (CW) = Back face

Right-hand rule: - Curl fingers in vertex order - Thumb points in normal direction

docs.title: Normals Point Outward
docs.text:
Properly oriented mesh: - All normals point away from solid - Defines "inside" vs "outside" - Essential for booleans

Flip normals: Reverses inside/outside

docs.title: Manifold Requirements
docs.text:
For robust boolean operations, meshes should be:

✅ Closed - No holes or open edges ✅ Non-self-intersecting - No overlapping faces ✅ Proper winding - Consistent face orientation ✅ Two-manifold - Each edge has exactly 2 faces ✅ No duplicate vertices - Welded properly

Check: - Sphere ✅ (closed ball) - Box ✅ (closed cube) - Plane ❌ (open, has boundary) - Overlapping cubes ❌ (self-intersecting)

docs.title: Vertex Count
docs.text:
More vertices = more computation:

Sphere Segments: 8  → 96 vertices  (fast)
Sphere Segments: 64 → 6144 vertices (slower)

Balance: - Use low poly for iteration - Increase detail for final output

docs.title: Triangle Count
docs.text:
Directly affects: - Boolean operation speed - Rendering performance - File size

Optimize: - Only subdivide where needed - Use LOD (Level of Detail) for distance

docs.title: Attribute Overhead
docs.text:
Each attribute adds memory:

1000 vertices × 12 attributes = 12,000 data points

Best practice: - Delete unused attributes - Only create what you need

docs.title: 1. Keep Meshes Clean
docs.text:
• Remove duplicate vertices
  • Ensure proper normals
  • Avoid self-intersections

docs.title: 2. Use Appropriate Resolution
docs.text:
✅ Low poly for base shape → Subdivide for detail
❌ Start with ultra-high poly

docs.title: 3. Understand Node Impact
docs.text:
• Generators: Create topology
  • Modifiers: Often preserve topology
  • Booleans: Create new topology

docs.title: 4. Check Manifold Status
docs.text:
• Test booleans on simple geometry first
  • If boolean fails, check input meshes

docs.title: Mesh Looks Inside-Out
docs.text:
Cause: Normals flipped

Fix: - Check vertex winding order - Use Reverse node (if available) - Recreate with correct orientation

docs.title: Boolean Operation Fails
docs.text:
Cause: Non-manifold inputs

Fix: - Verify both meshes are closed - Check for self-intersections - Simplify geometry if too complex

docs.title: Weird Shading
docs.text:
Cause: Inconsistent normals

Fix: - Recalculate normals (Smooth node) - Check for duplicate vertices - Ensure consistent winding

docs.title: Gaps in Mesh
docs.text:
Cause: Non-welded vertices

Fix: - Use Merge node with weld enabled - Check tolerance settings

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Learn Attributes - Attributes
  • Understand Groups - Groups
  • See Examples - Quick Start
  • Try Workflows - Architectural Modeling

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
✅ Meshes = Vertices + Edges + Faces (triangles) ✅ Manifold = Closed, watertight, valid for booleans ✅ Attributes = Data stored on vertices/faces ✅ Normals = Direction vectors for shading ✅ Topology = Connectivity (how it's built) ✅ Geometry = Shape (where vertices are)

Remember: Clean topology → Successful procedural operations!

docs.title: Groups
docs.text: Groups let you select and operate on subsets of geometry. They're essential for targeted operations like "delete only the top faces" or "extrude just the windows."

docs.title: What are Groups?
docs.text:
A group is a named selection of geometry components (points, edges, or faces).

Complete Mesh:  ●●●●●●●●●●  (10 vertices)
                ↓
Group "top":    ●●●○○○○○○○  (3 vertices selected)

Think of groups as filters that let operations affect only specific parts.

docs.title: Targeted Operations
docs.text:
Without groups: 

Extrude → Affects entire mesh

With groups: 

Group (top faces) → Extrude → Only top faces extrude

docs.title: Named Selections
docs.text:
Save selections for reuse: 

Create group "windows" → Use in multiple operations

docs.title: Complex Workflows
docs.text:
Build sophisticated procedural models: 

1. Select every other face → Group "pattern_a"
2. Select remaining faces → Group "pattern_b"
3. Color pattern_a red, pattern_b blue

docs.title: Point Groups
docs.text:
Select vertices: 

Group all points where @P.y > 0.5

Use for: - Vertex-based deformations - Color assignments - Position-based selections

docs.title: Edge Groups
docs.text:
Select edges: 

Group edges forming boundary loops

Use for: - Beveling specific edges - Edge-based selections

docs.title: Primitive (Face) Groups
docs.text:
Select triangles: 

Group faces where @materialid == 2

Use for: - Material assignments - Face deletion - Per-face operations

docs.title: Creating Groups
docs.text: Use the Group node to create selections.

docs.title: Method 1: Pattern-Based
docs.text:
Select by index patterns:

Example: Every Other Vertex 

Group Node:
- Mode: Pattern
- Pattern: "0-100:2"  (0, 2, 4, 6, ... every 2nd)
- Group Name: "alternating"

Pattern Syntax: 

0-10        → Indices 0 through 10
0,5,10      → Specific indices 0, 5, 10
0-100:2     → Every 2nd index (step of 2)
0-50,75-100 → Ranges 0-50 and 75-100

docs.title: Method 2: Expression-Based
docs.text:
Select by attribute values:

Example: Upper Half 

Group Node:
- Mode: Expression
- Expression: @P.y > 0.0
- Group Name: "upper_half"

Common Expressions: 

@P.y > 0.5              → Top vertices
@P.x < 0 and @P.z < 0   → Quadrant selection
@Cd.r > 0.8             → Red vertices
@id % 2 == 0            → Even IDs
length(@P) < 2.0        → Within radius

docs.title: Method 3: Manual
docs.text: Future feature: Click to select in viewport

docs.title: Deletion
docs.text:
Group Delete node removes selected geometry:

Sphere
  ↓
Group (Expression: @P.y < 0)  → Select bottom half
  ↓
Group Delete                   → Remove bottom
  ↓
Result: Hemisphere

docs.title: Material Assignment
docs.text:
Assign materials to grouped faces:

Box
  ↓
Group (Expression: @P.y > 0.99)  → Top face
  ↓
Attribute Create:
  Name: materialid
  Value: 2                       → Material ID 2 for top

docs.title: Conditional Extrusion
docs.text:
Extrude only selected faces:

Grid
  ↓
Group (Pattern: "0-100:3")  → Every 3rd face
  ↓
Extrude (if group exists, only affects grouped faces)

docs.title: Combining Groups
docs.text:
Group Combine node merges or intersects groups:

Union (A or B): 

Group A: "top_faces"
Group B: "side_faces"
  ↓
Group Combine: Union
  ↓
Result: "top_or_side" (all faces in either group)

Intersection (A and B): 

Group A: "red_vertices"  (@Cd.r > 0.8)
Group B: "top_vertices"  (@P.y > 0.5)
  ↓
Group Combine: Intersection
  ↓
Result: "red_and_top" (only vertices in both groups)

Subtraction (A not B): 

Group A: "all_faces"
Group B: "bottom_faces"
  ↓
Group Combine: Subtract
  ↓
Result: "not_bottom" (A minus B)

docs.title: Inverting Groups
docs.text:
Select everything not in group:

Group "selected"
  ↓
Group Combine: Invert
  ↓
Result: "not_selected"

docs.title: Checkerboard Selection
docs.text:
Grid (10×10 cells)
  ↓
Group:
  Mode: Expression
  Expression: (floor(@P.x) + floor(@P.z)) % 2 == 0
  Group: "checkers"
  ↓
Group Delete → Removes every other cell

docs.title: Ring Selection
docs.text:
Cylinder
  ↓
Group:
  Mode: Expression
  Expression: abs(@P.y - 0.5) < 0.1
  Group: "ring"
  ↓
Extrude → Only middle ring extrudes

docs.title: Border Selection
docs.text:
Grid
  ↓
Group:
  Mode: Expression
  Expression: abs(@P.x) > 0.9 or abs(@P.z) > 0.9
  Group: "border"

docs.title: Random Selection
docs.text:
Sphere
  ↓
Group:
  Mode: Expression
  Expression: rand(@id) > 0.5
  Group: "random_half"

docs.title: Height Gradient
docs.text:
Cylinder
  ↓
Group:
  Mode: Expression
  Expression: @P.y > $threshold
  Group: "above_threshold"

(Change $threshold to select different heights)

docs.title: Comparison Operators
docs.text:
@P.y > 0.5          → Greater than
@P.y < 0.5          → Less than
@P.y >= 0.5         → Greater or equal
@P.y <= 0.5         → Less or equal
@P.y == 0.5         → Equal (exactly)
@P.y != 0.5         → Not equal

docs.title: Logical Operators
docs.text:
@P.y > 0 and @P.x > 0       → AND (both true)
@P.y > 0 or @P.x > 0        → OR (either true)
not (@P.y > 0)              → NOT (invert)

docs.title: Complex Conditions
docs.text:
(@P.y > 0.5 and @P.y < 0.8) or @Cd.r > 0.9
→ Select if (Y between 0.5 and 0.8) OR (very red)

docs.title: Math Functions
docs.text:
length(@P) < 2.0                → Within radius 2
abs(@P.x - @P.z) < 0.1          → Near diagonal
sin(@P.x * 10) > 0              → Wavy pattern
floor(@P.x) % 2 == 0            → Stripe pattern

docs.title: Delete Bottom Half
docs.text:
1. Sphere
2. Group:
   Expression: @P.y < 0
   Group: "bottom"
3. Group Delete

docs.title: Color Stripes
docs.text:
1. Grid
2. Group:
   Expression: floor(@P.x * 5) % 2 == 0
   Group: "stripes"
3. Attribute Create:
   Name: Cd
   Value: @stripes ? [1,0,0] : [0,0,1]

(Red and blue stripes)

docs.title: Extrude Windows
docs.text:
1. Box
2. Group:
   Expression: @P.z > 0.99  (front face)
   Group: "front"
3. Subdivide (to create face grid)
4. Group:
   Pattern: "0-100:3"  (every 3rd face)
   Group: "windows"
5. Extrude (inward for window recesses)

docs.title: Scatter on Selection
docs.text:
1. Grid
2. Group:
   Expression: rand(@id) > 0.7
   Group: "scatter_points"
3. Scatter (uses group as distribution)

docs.title: Group Attributes
docs.text:
Groups are stored as point/face attributes:

Group "selected" creates:
@selected = 1  (in group)
@selected = 0  (not in group)

Access in expressions: 

@selected == 1  → Check if in group
@mygroup        → Direct group check

docs.title: 1. Name Groups Clearly
docs.text:
✅ "top_faces", "window_locations", "border_verts"
❌ "group1", "sel", "temp"

docs.title: 2. Document Complex Expressions
docs.text:
Expression: (@P.y > $base_height) and (rand(@id) > $density)
Comment: "Select random points above base height"

docs.title: 3. Test on Simple Geometry
docs.text:
✅ Test expression on Sphere → Apply to complex model
❌ Write complex expression on 10k poly mesh (hard to debug)

docs.title: 4. Use Graph Parameters
docs.text:
Expression: @P.y > $select_threshold

Now $select_threshold is adjustable in UI!

docs.title: 5. Visualize Groups
docs.text:
Use colors to verify selections: 

Group (create selection)
  ↓
Attribute Create:
  Name: Cd
  Value: @groupname ? [1,0,0] : [0,1,0]

Red = in group, Green = not in group

docs.title: Group Not Selecting Anything
docs.text:
Check: 1. Expression syntax correct? 2. Attribute exists? (e.g., @P always exists) 3. Value ranges? (is @P.y ever > 0.5?) 4. Group type matches (point vs face)?

Debug: 

Add Attribute Create: @debug = @P.y
View values in viewport

docs.title: Wrong Geometry Selected
docs.text: Fix: 1. Simplify expression 2. Test components: @P.y > 0 first, add more conditions later 3. Visualize with colors

docs.title: Group Not Affecting Operation
docs.text: Check: 1. Does node support groups? 2. Group name matches? 3. Group was created upstream?

docs.title: Multi-Level Selection
docs.text:
1. Group A: "upper_half" (@P.y > 0)
2. Within A, Group B: "upper_corners" (@P.x > 0.5)
3. Result: Corners of upper half

docs.title: Animated Selection
docs.text:
With graph parameters: 

Expression: @P.y < $cutoff_height

Animate $cutoff_height → Moving selection plane

docs.title: Geometric Patterns
docs.text:
Radial: length([@P.x, @P.z]) < $radius
Grid: (floor(@P.x) + floor(@P.z)) % 2 == 0
Spiral: atan2(@P.z, @P.x) + length([@P.x,@P.z]) < $param

docs.title: Neighbor-Based
docs.text: Future: Select based on neighboring vertices

docs.title: Optimize Expressions
docs.text:
✅ @P.y > 0  (fast: single comparison)
❌ length(@P - [complex_calc]) > threshold  (slow: many ops)

docs.title: Cache Groups
docs.text:
If using same selection multiple times: 

✅ Create group once → Use many times
❌ Recreate selection in every node

docs.title: Pattern vs Expression
docs.text:
Pattern mode: Fast for index-based selections
Expression mode: Flexible but slower for complex math

docs.title: Delete Every Other Face
docs.text:
Grid
  ↓
Group:
  Mode: Pattern
  Pattern: "0-1000:2"
  ↓
Group Delete

docs.title: Color by Distance
docs.text:
Sphere
  ↓
Group:
  Expression: length(@P) < 0.8
  Group: "inner"
  ↓
Attribute Create:
  Cd: @inner ? [1,0,0] : [0,0,1]

docs.title: Mask with Noise
docs.text:
Grid
  ↓
Attribute Create:
  Name: noise_val
  Value: rand(@id)
  ↓
Group:
  Expression: @noise_val > $threshold

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Use Groups in Workflows - Procedural Patterns
  • See Group Node - Group Node Reference
  • Learn Attributes - Attributes
  • Advanced Selection - Expression Syntax

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
✅ Groups = Named selections of geometry subsets ✅ Types = Point, Edge, Face (primitive) groups ✅ Creation = Pattern (indices) or Expression (attributes) ✅ Operations = Combine, Intersect, Subtract, Invert ✅ Uses = Targeted deletion, coloring, extrusion, etc. ✅ Stored as = Attributes (@groupname)

Remember: Groups are the key to selective operations - enabling complex procedural control!

docs.title: Node Graph Basics
docs.text: The node graph is your workspace in Nodo. Understanding how it works is essential to building procedural models efficiently.

docs.title: What is a Node Graph?
docs.text:
A node graph is a visual representation of operations and data flow:

┌─────────┐     ┌───────────┐     ┌────────┐
│ Input A │────→│ Operation │────→│ Output │
└─────────┘     └───────────┘     └────────┘
       ↓
┌─────────┐
│ Input B │
└─────────┘

Think of it as: A flowchart where: - Nodes = Operations or generators - Connections = Data flowing between nodes - Parameters = Settings that control each node

docs.title: Node Components
docs.text:
1. Title Bar - Node name (double-click to rename) - Node type/category - Status indicators

2. Input Ports (Left Side) - Circles where connections attach - Accept geometry from other nodes - Can have multiple inputs (e.g., Boolean node)

3. Parameters (Middle Section) - Adjustable values (sliders, spinboxes) - Expression mode available (click ≡ button) - Control the node's behavior

4. Output Port (Right Side) - Single circle sending data downstream - Can connect to multiple nodes

docs.title: Left to Right
docs.text:
Data flows left → right in Nodo:

Generator → Modifier → Modifier → Output
(Creates)   (Changes)  (Refines)  (Result)

Example: 

Sphere → Transform → Subdivide → Final Mesh

docs.title: Execution Order
docs.text:
Nodo automatically determines execution order:

     A
    ↙ ↘
   B   C
    ↘ ↙
     D

Execution: A → B → C → D (parallel paths merge at D)

Key Point: You don't specify order - connections define it!

docs.title: 1. Generator Nodes
docs.text:
Purpose: Create geometry from scratch

Examples: - Sphere, Box, Cylinder, Torus - Grid, Line

Characteristics: - No input ports (create data) - Generate base geometry - Controlled by parameters only

Use: Starting points for any model

docs.title: 2. Modifier Nodes
docs.text:
Purpose: Change existing geometry

Examples: - Transform, Extrude, Smooth - Subdivide, Mirror, Bend, Twist

Characteristics: - One input port (geometry to modify) - One output port (modified result) - Chain together for complex effects

Use: Refine and shape geometry

docs.title: 3. Boolean Nodes
docs.text:
Purpose: Combine multiple geometries

Examples: - Boolean (Union/Subtract/Intersect) - Merge (Combine without CSG)

Characteristics: - Multiple input ports - Combine or cut geometry - Order matters (A subtract B ≠ B subtract A)

Use: Complex shapes from simple primitives

docs.title: 4. Array Nodes
docs.text:
Purpose: Duplicate and distribute

Examples: - Array (linear/grid/circular) - Scatter (random distribution) - Copy to Points (instance at positions)

Characteristics: - Input: geometry to duplicate - Output: many copies - Powerful for patterns

Use: Repetition and instancing

docs.title: 5. Attribute Nodes
docs.text:
Purpose: Manage vertex/face data

Examples: - Attribute Create - Attribute Delete - Color

Characteristics: - Modify per-point/face attributes - Enable advanced workflows - Support expressions

Use: Data-driven modeling

docs.title: 6. Group Nodes
docs.text:
Purpose: Select and filter geometry

Examples: - Group (select by pattern/expression) - Group Delete (remove selected) - Group Combine (merge selections)

Characteristics: - Create named selections - Filter operations to subsets - Powerful with expressions

Use: Selective operations

docs.title: How to Connect
docs.text:
1. Click and drag from an output port
  2. Release on an input port
  3. Connection appears as a line

Visual: 

[Node A] ○────→ ○ [Node B]
        output  input

docs.title: Connection Rules
docs.text:
✅ Can Connect: - Output → Input - One output → Many inputs (branching) - Compatible types (geometry → geometry)

❌ Cannot Connect: - Input → Output (wrong direction) - Input → Input - Output → Output

docs.title: Disconnecting
docs.text:
• Click the connection line → Select it
  • Press Delete or Backspace
  • Or drag output to empty space

docs.title: Panning
docs.text:
• Middle mouse button + drag
  • Or Space + Left mouse drag

docs.title: Zooming
docs.text:
• Mouse wheel scroll
  • Ctrl + Middle mouse drag

docs.title: Framing
docs.text:
• F key - Frame selected node(s)
  • A key - Frame all nodes

docs.title: Creating Nodes
docs.text:
Method 1: Tab Menu 1. Press Tab in graph 2. Type to search (e.g., "sphere") 3. Click or press Enter

Method 2: Right-Click Menu 1. Right-click in graph 2. Navigate categories 3. Select node

Method 3: Keyboard Shortcuts - S - Add Sphere - B - Add Box - T - Add Transform - (See full list in Keyboard Shortcuts)

docs.title: Selecting Nodes
docs.text:
• Left-click - Select single node
  • Ctrl + Left-click - Add to selection
  • Click + Drag box around nodes - Multi-select
  • Ctrl + A - Select all

docs.title: Moving Nodes
docs.text:
• Left-click and drag node
  • Or select + arrow keys for precise placement

docs.title: Deleting Nodes
docs.text:
• Select node(s)
  • Press Delete or Backspace
  • Connections are removed automatically

docs.title: Duplicating Nodes
docs.text:
• Select node(s)
  • Ctrl + D - Duplicate
  • Connections are NOT copied

docs.title: Copying Parameters
docs.text:
• Ctrl + C on parameter value
  • Ctrl + V on target parameter
  • Or right-click → Copy/Paste Value

docs.title: Dependency Chain
docs.text:
Each node waits for its inputs:

A ───→ B ───→ C
       ↑
D ─────┘

Execution: A, D → B (when both ready) → C

docs.title: Live Evaluation
docs.text:
Nodo evaluates on-demand:

  1. You change a parameter
  2. Node marks itself "dirty"
  3. All downstream nodes mark dirty
  4. Display node re-executes chain
  5. Viewport updates

Result: Only affected nodes re-execute (efficient!).

docs.title: Circular Dependencies
docs.text:
Not allowed: 

A → B → C → A  ❌ Creates infinite loop

Nodo will detect and warn about cycles.

docs.title: 1. Organize Your Graph
docs.text:
Good Layout: 

┌──────┐    ┌───────┐    ┌───────┐
│ Gen  │───→│ Mod 1 │───→│ Mod 2 │───→ Output
└──────┘    └───────┘    └───────┘

Bad Layout: 

    ┌─────┐
    │Gen  │
    └──┬──┘
       ↓
    ┌──┴──────┐
    │  Mod    │←──┐
    └─────────┘   │
          ↓       │
       [Tangled mess]

Tips: - Keep flow left → right - Align nodes vertically when possible - Use space to group related nodes

docs.title: 2. Name Your Nodes
docs.text:
✅ "base_cylinder", "window_array", "roof_detail"
❌ "cylinder_1", "array_5", "merge_12"

How: Double-click title → Type new name

docs.title: 3. Use Comments
docs.text:
Future feature: Sticky notes to annotate graphs

Current: Use descriptive node names as documentation

docs.title: 4. Break Into Sections
docs.text:
Conceptual stages:

[Base Geometry] → [Primary Details] → [Secondary Details] → [Finishing]

Visually separate with spacing.

docs.title: 5. Avoid Spaghetti
docs.text:
Too many crossing connections = hard to read

Solution: - Rearrange nodes to minimize crossings - Consider using subgraphs (future feature)

docs.title: Linear Chain
docs.text:
A → B → C → D → Output

Use: Sequential operations (build, refine, finish)

docs.title: Parallel Branches
docs.text:
A
   ↙ ↘
  B   C
   ↘ ↙
    D

Use: Combine separate parts (e.g., base + details)

docs.title: Scatter-Gather
docs.text:
A
    ↙ ↓ ↘
   B  C  D
    ↘ ↓ ↙
      E

Use: Apply variations, then merge

docs.title: Feedback Loop (via Parameters)
docs.text:
A → B → C
    ↑
    └─ ch("../c/output_value")

Use: One-way parameter references (not geometry cycles)

docs.title: Nodo is Spatial, Not Temporal
docs.text:
Not Like: - Video editing (timeline-based) - Animation software (keyframe-based)

More Like: - Programming flowcharts - Data processing pipelines - Spreadsheet formulas

Key Difference: - No "playhead" or "current time" - Graph is the complete procedure - Evaluate, don't animate (yet)

docs.title: Node Not Updating?
docs.text: Check: 1. Is it connected to the output chain? 2. Are inputs valid (connected nodes)? 3. Are parameters in valid ranges? 4. Any error indicators on node?

docs.title: Unexpected Result?
docs.text: Isolate: 1. Select node producing wrong result 2. Temporarily delete downstream nodes 3. Examine intermediate output 4. Narrow down problem node

docs.title: Performance Issues?
docs.text: Optimize: 1. Check for accidentally high poly counts 2. Disable expensive nodes while tweaking 3. Use lower resolution for preview 4. Optimize execution order

docs.title: Expression-Driven Graphs
docs.text:
Use expressions to automate:

Array Count = ceil($building_height / $floor_height)

Now array adapts to building height automatically!

docs.title: Graph Parameters
docs.text:
Expose controls in Graph Parameters panel:

$master_scale - Controls all size parameters
$detail_level - Switches LOD variants
$random_seed  - Changes all randomization

docs.title: Cross-Node References
docs.text:
Link parameters between nodes:

Cylinder radius = ch("../sphere/radius") * 0.5

Cylinder automatically half of sphere's size!

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text:
Essential graph shortcuts:

Action Shortcut Create Node Tab Delete Delete / Backspace Duplicate Ctrl + D Select All Ctrl + A Frame All A Frame Selected F Pan MMB drag / Space + LMB Zoom Scroll wheel

See Full Shortcuts List

docs.text:

  • Use Groups - Groups
  • Try a Workflow - Architectural Modeling

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
✅ Node graphs = Visual flowcharts for 3D procedures ✅ Data flows left → right through connections ✅ Nodes = Generators, Modifiers, Booleans, Arrays, etc. ✅ Live evaluation - Changes propagate instantly ✅ Organize for readability (naming, layout, spacing) ✅ Think procedurally - Build generators, not static models

Remember: A good node graph is like good code - readable, organized, and maintainable!

docs.title: Procedural Modeling
docs.text: Procedural modeling is a fundamentally different approach to 3D creation compared to traditional polygon modeling. Understanding this paradigm is key to mastering Nodo.

docs.title: What is Procedural Modeling?
docs.text: Procedural modeling means defining your 3D models through recipes (procedures) rather than manual sculpting.

docs.title: Traditional Modeling
docs.text:
[Artist] → [Direct Manipulation] → [Final Model]
         ↓
    Move vertices, extrude faces, sculpt directly
    Result: Static geometry

Characteristics: - Manual vertex-by-vertex editing - Fixed, "baked" geometry - Hard to modify after completion - Changes require re-modeling

docs.title: Procedural Modeling
docs.text:
[Artist] → [Define Rules/Parameters] → [System Generates Model]
         ↓
    Set parameters, create node networks
    Result: Dynamic, adjustable geometry

Characteristics: - Parameter-driven generation - Easily adjustable at any time - Repeatable and consistent - Non-destructive workflow

docs.title: 1. Infinite Variations
docs.text:
Change a single parameter to generate completely different results:

Building Generator:
- Height: 50m → 200m      (instant update)
- Floors: 10 → 40         (rebuilds windows)
- Style: Modern → Gothic  (regenerates details)

Use Case: Create 100 unique buildings from one node graph.

docs.title: 2. Non-Destructive Editing
docs.text:
Every step remains editable:

Traditional: Box → Bevel → Subdivide → Extrude
            [Can't easily change box size now]

Procedural:  Box Node → Bevel Node → Subdivide Node → Extrude Node
            [Can change box size anytime, propagates through chain]

Use Case: Client wants taller building after you've added windows? Just change the height parameter.

docs.title: 3. Automation & Scale
docs.text:
Create complex results from simple rules:

Pattern Generator:
- Input: Single tile
- Rule: Array with rotation + noise
- Output: 1000 unique variations

Use Case: Generate an entire forest, city block, or tiled floor with minimal manual work.

docs.title: 4. Consistency
docs.text:
Maintain design rules across variations:

Graph Parameter: $window_spacing = 2.5m
All windows on all floors respect this spacing
Change to 3.0m → Everything updates consistently

Use Case: Ensure architectural standards across a project.

docs.title: 5. Rapid Iteration
docs.text:
Test ideas quickly:

Tweak parameter → See result immediately
Try 10 different column counts in 30 seconds

Use Case: Explore design options without rebuilding from scratch.

docs.title: 1. Nodes, Not Vertices
docs.text:
Think in operations, not points:

  • Traditional: "I'll move these 47 vertices"
  • Procedural: "I'll apply a Transform node"

docs.title: 2. Parameters, Not Fixed Values
docs.text:
Think in variables:

  • Traditional: "This is 10 units tall"
  • Procedural: "Height = $floor_count * $floor_height"

docs.title: 3. Data Flow, Not States
docs.text:
Think in connections:

  • Traditional: "Current state of model"
  • Procedural: "Output of this node → Input of next node"

docs.title: 4. Rules, Not Details
docs.text:
Think in systems:

  • Traditional: "Place each window manually"
  • Procedural: "Array windows based on spacing rule"

docs.title: Ideal For:
docs.text:
✅ Repetitive Structures - Buildings, fences, stairs, pipes - Anything with regular patterns

✅ Parametric Designs - Furniture with adjustable dimensions - Mechanical parts with specifications

✅ Large-Scale Generation - Cities, forests, crowds - Level geometry for games

✅ Exploratory Design - Trying many variations quickly - Generative art and experiments

✅ Production Assets - Game props needing LOD variants - Background elements needing variety

docs.title: Less Ideal For:
docs.text:
❌ Organic Sculpting - Character faces, creatures - Free-form artistic sculpting - (Better: ZBrush, Blender sculpt mode)

❌ One-Off Unique Models - Single hero asset with unique details - (Though procedural base + manual details works well)

❌ High-Frequency Detail - Wrinkles, pores, tiny imperfections - (Better: Displacement maps, normal maps)

docs.title: Nodo's Approach
docs.text:
Nodo implements procedural modeling through node graphs:

┌─────────┐     ┌───────────┐     ┌────────┐
│  Sphere │────→│ Transform │────→│ Merge  │────→ Final Geometry
└─────────┘     └───────────┘     └────────┘
                                       ↑
                ┌──────┐              │
                │ Grid │──────────────┘
                └──────┘

Key Features:

  1. Visual Programming - See the flow of operations
  2. Live Updates - Change propagates instantly
  3. Expression System - Parameters can be formulas
  4. Reusable Graphs - Save and reuse node networks

docs.title: The Procedural Mindset
docs.text:
Instead of asking:

"How do I model this?"

Ask:

"What are the rules that generate this?"

Example: Modeling a Brick Wall

Traditional Thinking: - Place first brick - Copy brick 10 times - Stack rows - Add mortar gaps - Randomize slightly

Procedural Thinking: - Define: brick size, mortar width, pattern - Rules: offset every other row, randomize height ±5% - Generate: array fills area based on rules

Result: Adjust wall size, brick size, pattern - instant update!

docs.title: Practical Example: Tower
docs.text:
Goal: Procedural tower with adjustable parameters

Graph: 

Cylinder (base)
    ↓
Transform (stretch to height)
    ↓
Array (duplicate for floors)
    ↓
Merge (with windows)
    ↓
Boolean (subtract door)

Parameters: - $tower_height → Adjusts cylinder transform - $floor_count → Adjusts array count - $floor_height = $tower_height / $floor_count

Power: Change tower from 50m to 200m instantly. Add floors without rebuilding. Swap cylinder for octagon base.

docs.title: Advanced Phase

docs.title: Channel References
docs.text: Channel references let you access parameter values from other nodes using the ch() function. This is essential for creating interconnected, data-driven procedural systems.

docs.title: What is a Channel Reference?
docs.text:
A channel is any parameter in your node graph. A channel reference is a way to read that parameter's value from anywhere else in the graph.

Think of it as "linking" to a parameter rather than copying its value.

docs.title: Basic Syntax
docs.text:
ch("path/to/parameter")

The path specifies which node and which parameter to reference.

docs.title: Relative Paths
docs.text:
Relative to the current node:

ch("parameter_name")          # Current node's parameter
ch("../other_node/radius")    # Sibling node's parameter
ch("../../control")           # Parent's parameter
ch("../../../global")         # Grandparent's parameter

Path components: - . = Current node - .. = Parent (go up one level) - node_name = Child node (go down into named node)

docs.title: Absolute Paths
docs.text:
From the graph root:

ch("/graph/master_scale")     # Graph parameter
ch("/node_name/parameter")    # Top-level node

Paths starting with / are absolute.

docs.title: Reference Sibling Node
docs.text:
Most common case: reference a parameter from another node at the same level.

ch("../sphere/radius")
ch("../transform/translate.x")
ch("../array/count")

Example: 

# Box node references Sphere's radius
size_x = ch("../sphere/radius") * 2
size_y = ch("../sphere/radius") * 2
size_z = ch("../sphere/radius") * 2

Now the box automatically sizes to the sphere!

docs.title: Reference Graph Parameter
docs.text:
Access graph-level parameters:

ch("/graph/master_scale")
ch("/graph/detail_level")

Or use the shorthand:

$master_scale        # Equivalent to ch("/graph/master_scale")
$detail_level        # Equivalent to ch("/graph/detail_level")

docs.title: Reference Current Node
docs.text:
Access another parameter in the same node:

ch("radius")         # Current node's radius
ch("size_x")         # Current node's size_x

Useful for derived calculations:

# In a Transform node
translate_y = ch("translate_x") * 2
scale_z = ch("scale_x")          # Lock Z to X

docs.title: Vector Components
docs.text:
Access individual components of vector parameters:

ch("translate.x")      # X component
ch("translate.y")      # Y component
ch("translate.z")      # Z component

docs.title: Method 1: Node Names
docs.text:
Nodes are referenced by their name. By default: - sphere → Sphere node - transform → Transform node - array → Array node

But if you rename a node, use the new name: - tower_base → Node renamed to "tower_base" - detail_copy → Node renamed to "detail_copy"

Rename for Clarity

Rename nodes to make paths more readable: 

ch("../tower_base/height")    # Clear!
ch("../box/size_y")            # Generic

docs.title: Method 2: Copy Parameter Path
docs.text: Future feature: Right-click parameter → "Copy Path"

docs.title: Method 3: Inspect Node Tree
docs.text:
Look at your node graph hierarchy:

Root
├── sphere_1
├── transform_1
│   └── input: sphere_1
└── array_1
    └── input: transform_1

From array_1 to reference sphere_1: 

ch("../../sphere_1/radius")    # Up twice, down to sphere_1

docs.title: Linked Dimensions
docs.text:
Keep dimensions synchronized:

# Box node
size_x = $base_size
size_y = size_x         # ERROR: Can't self-reference
size_y = ch("size_x")   # Correct!
size_z = ch("size_x")

docs.title: Proportional Scaling
docs.text:
Scale one object based on another:

# Cylinder references Sphere
radius = ch("../sphere/radius") * 0.5  # Half of sphere
height = ch("../sphere/radius") * 3    # Three times radius

docs.title: Responsive Arrays
docs.text:
Array count based on size:

# Array node
count = ceil(ch("../base/size_x") / $spacing)

As base size changes, array count adapts!

docs.title: Conditional Behavior
docs.text:
Use referenced values in conditions:

# Switch node
input_index = ch("../control/value") > 0.5 ? 1 : 0

docs.title: Cascading Parameters
docs.text:
Chain parameters through multiple nodes:

# Node A
value_a = $master * 2

# Node B
value_b = ch("../node_a/value_a") * 1.5

# Node C
value_c = ch("../node_b/value_b") + 10

docs.title: Cross-Branch References
docs.text:
Reference nodes in different branches:

# From one branch to another
ch("../../branch_a/node_1/value")

docs.title: Bidirectional Links
docs.text:
Create interdependent parameters:

# Node A
width = $base_width
height = ch("../node_b/height") * 2

# Node B
height = $base_height
width = ch("../node_a/width") * 0.5

Circular References

Avoid circular dependencies: 

# Node A: ch("../node_b/value")
# Node B: ch("../node_a/value")
# ❌ This creates a loop!

docs.title: Dynamic Path Building
docs.text:
Not currently supported - paths must be literal strings.

Future: ch("../" + $node_name + "/radius")

docs.title: "Parameter not found"
docs.text:
Cause: Path is incorrect or node/parameter doesn't exist.

Solutions: - Check node name spelling (case-sensitive!) - Verify node exists in graph - Check parameter name spelling - Ensure you have the right number of ../ for hierarchy

docs.title: "Circular reference detected"
docs.text:
Cause: Parameter depends on itself (directly or indirectly).

Example: 

# Node A
value = ch("../node_b/value")

# Node B
value = ch("../node_a/value")

Solution: - Break the loop by using a fixed value somewhere - Restructure your graph to avoid circular flow

docs.title: Reference doesn't update
docs.text:
Cause: Expression isn't evaluating or node is disabled.

Solutions: - Check expression mode is enabled (parameter is blue) - Verify referenced node is enabled - Try re-entering the expression

docs.title: Wrong value returned
docs.text:
Cause: Referencing wrong node or parameter.

Solutions: - Double-check path is correct - Verify node names (check if renamed) - Print value for debugging: ch("path") + 0

docs.title: From Current Node
docs.text: Target Path Same node ch("parameter") Sibling node ch("../other_node/parameter") Parent level ch("../../parent_param") Graph parameter ch("/graph/param") or $param

docs.title: Going Up the Tree
docs.text:
ch("parameter")              # Current node
ch("../sibling/parameter")   # Up 1, down to sibling
ch("../../parent/parameter") # Up 2, down to parent

docs.title: Going Down the Tree
docs.text:
ch("child/parameter")           # Direct child
ch("child/grandchild/parameter") # Nested children

docs.title: Use Descriptive Node Names
docs.text:
Before Referencing

Rename nodes to describe their purpose: 

Double-click node → Type "tower_base"

Then reference: 

ch("../tower_base/height")   # Clear intent

docs.title: Keep Paths Short
docs.text:
Organize Hierarchy

Structure your graph to minimize ../../../ paths.

Consider using Graph Parameters for values needed everywhere.

docs.title: Document Complex References
docs.text: Use graph parameter descriptions to explain complex cross-references.

docs.title: Prefer Graph Parameters for Globals
docs.text:
Instead of: 

# Many nodes referencing one node
ch("../../control_node/value")

Better: 

# Create a graph parameter instead
$control_value

docs.title: Comparison: ch() vs Graph Parameters
docs.text:
Feature ch() Graph Parameters Scope Any node parameter Graph-level only Syntax ch("path") $name Flexibility Can reference any parameter Dedicated controls Organization Can get messy Clean central panel Performance Same Same

When to use ch(): - Quick references between nearby nodes - One-off parameter links - Reading calculated values from other nodes

When to use Graph Parameters: - Values used by many nodes - Primary controls for your system - Values you want in a clean UI panel

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Graph Parameters - Creating reusable parameters
  • Expression Syntax - Expression language
  • Math Functions - Available functions

Practice Path Writing:

Given this graph: 

root
├── base
│   └── size_x
├── details
│   ├── column
│   │   └── radius
│   └── cap
│       └── height

From cap to reference base.size_x: 

ch("../../base/size_x")

From column to reference cap.height: 

ch("../cap/height")

From base to reference column.radius: 

ch("../details/column/radius")

docs.title: Expression Syntax
docs.text: Complete reference for the expression language in Nodo. Expressions let you use mathematical formulas and logic to drive parameter values dynamically.

docs.title: What are Expressions?
docs.text:
Expressions are math formulas you can write in parameter fields instead of fixed values. They enable:

  • Dynamic values - Parameters that calculate based on other values
  • Procedural control - Math-driven geometry
  • Responsive designs - Models that adapt automatically
  • Complex relationships - Link parameters across nodes

docs.title: Switching Between Modes
docs.text:
Parameters that support expressions (Float, Int, Vector3) have a mode toggle button next to them:

  • ≡ icon = Numeric mode (spinbox/slider input)
  • # icon = Expression mode (text input for formulas)

To enable expression mode:

  1. Find the parameter you want to make dynamic
  2. Click the ≡ button next to the parameter value
  3. The button changes to # and a text field appears
  4. Type your expression (e.g., $radius * 2)
  5. Press Enter to apply

To return to numeric mode:

  1. Click the # button
  2. The button changes back to ≡ and the spinbox returns
  3. The last evaluated value is kept

Visual Feedback

  • Blue background = Valid expression
  • Red background = Syntax error
  • Hover over the field to see the resolved value

docs.title: Numbers
docs.text:
42          # Integer
3.14159     # Float
-10         # Negative
1.5e3       # Scientific notation (1500)

docs.title: Operators
docs.text:
Arithmetic: 

2 + 3       # Addition → 5
10 - 4      # Subtraction → 6
5 * 6       # Multiplication → 30
20 / 4      # Division → 5
10 % 3      # Modulo (remainder) → 1
2 ^ 8       # Power → 256

Comparison: 

5 > 3       # Greater than → true (1)
5 < 3       # Less than → false (0)
5 >= 5      # Greater or equal → true
5 <= 3      # Less or equal → false
5 == 5      # Equal → true
5 != 3      # Not equal → true

Logical: 

true and false   # AND → false
true or false    # OR → true
not true         # NOT → false

docs.title: Order of Operations
docs.text:
Follows standard math precedence (PEMDAS):

2 + 3 * 4       # → 14 (multiplication first)
(2 + 3) * 4     # → 20 (parentheses first)
2 ^ 3 + 1       # → 9 (power first)

docs.title: Graph Parameters
docs.text:
Reference graph parameters with $:

$radius             # Graph parameter named "radius"
$master_scale       # Graph parameter named "master_scale"

docs.title: Channel References
docs.text:
Reference other node parameters with ch():

ch("../sphere/radius")          # Sibling node's radius
ch("radius")                    # Current node's radius
ch("/graph/master_scale")       # Graph parameter
ch("../../control")             # Parent's parameter

See Channel References for path syntax.

docs.title: Built-in Variables
docs.text:
$F      # Current frame number (0 for now, animation coming)
$T      # Current time in seconds
$PI     # Pi constant (3.14159...)
$E      # Euler's number (2.71828...)

docs.title: Math Functions
docs.text:
Basic: 

abs(-5)         # Absolute value → 5
sqrt(16)        # Square root → 4
pow(2, 8)       # Power → 256

Rounding: 

floor(3.7)      # Round down → 3
ceil(3.2)       # Round up → 4
round(3.5)      # Round nearest → 4

Min/Max: 

min(5, 10)      # Minimum → 5
max(5, 10)      # Maximum → 10
clamp(15, 0, 10)  # Constrain → 10

Trigonometry (degrees): 

sin(45)         # Sine → 0.707
cos(90)         # Cosine → 0
tan(45)         # Tangent → 1
asin(0.5)       # Arc sine → 30
acos(0)         # Arc cosine → 90
atan(1)         # Arc tangent → 45
atan2(y, x)     # Two-argument arc tangent

Interpolation: 

lerp(0, 10, 0.5)     # Linear interpolate → 5
smoothstep(0, 10, 5)  # Smooth interpolate

See Math Functions for complete list.

docs.title: String Functions
docs.text:
str(42)         # Convert to string → "42"
len("hello")    # String length → 5

docs.title: Type Conversion
docs.text:
int(3.7)        # Convert to integer → 3
float(42)       # Convert to float → 42.0
bool(1)         # Convert to boolean → true

docs.title: Ternary Operator
docs.text:
condition ? value_if_true : value_if_false

Examples: 

$radius > 1.0 ? 32 : 16     # More segments if larger
$enable ? 1 : 0             # Boolean to number
$count >= 10 ? "many" : "few"  # Conditional string

docs.title: Chained Conditionals
docs.text:
$value < 0 ? "negative" :
$value == 0 ? "zero" :
"positive"

docs.title: Vector Components
docs.text:
Access X, Y, Z components:

ch("translate.x")       # X component
ch("translate.y")       # Y component
ch("translate.z")       # Z component

docs.title: Vector Functions
docs.text:
length(vec3(3, 4, 0))      # Magnitude → 5
distance(vec1, vec2)        # Distance between vectors
normalize(vector)           # Unit vector
dot(vec1, vec2)            # Dot product
cross(vec1, vec2)          # Cross product

docs.title: Vector Construction
docs.text:
vec3(1, 2, 3)              # Create vector
vec3($x, $y, 0)            # From parameters

docs.title: Responsive Scaling
docs.text:
# Maintain density as size changes
count = ceil($size / $target_spacing)
actual_spacing = $size / count

docs.title: Conditional Detail
docs.text:
# More detail for larger objects
segments = $radius > 1.0 ? 64 : 32

docs.title: Proportional Relationships
docs.text:
# Maintain aspect ratio
height = $width * 1.618  # Golden ratio
depth = $width * 0.5     # Half width

docs.title: Wave Functions
docs.text:
# Sine wave displacement
offset = sin($index * 360 / $total) * $amplitude

docs.title: Range Remapping
docs.text:
# Map 0-1 to min-max
remapped = $min + $normalized * ($max - $min)

docs.title: Noise-Based Variation
docs.text:
# Pseudo-random from index
variation = sin($index * 12.9898) * $amount

docs.title: Frame Selection
docs.text:
Toggle between inputs based on condition:

$use_high_detail ? 1 : 0  # Switch node input index

docs.title: Clamping Values
docs.text:
Ensure values stay in range:

clamp($input, $min, $max)
max($input, 0)  # Ensure non-negative

docs.title: Snap to Grid
docs.text:
Round to nearest multiple:

round($value / $grid_size) * $grid_size

docs.title: Percentage Calculation
docs.text: $partial / $total * 100  # Percentage

docs.title: Alternating Pattern
docs.text: $index % 2 == 0 ? $value_a : $value_b

docs.title: Exponential Growth
docs.text: pow(2, $level)  # Doubles each level

docs.title: Use Parentheses for Clarity
docs.text:
Make Intent Clear

# Less clear
2 + 3 * 4 - 1

# More clear
2 + (3 * 4) - 1

docs.title: Break Complex Expressions
docs.text:
Instead of one giant expression, use intermediate nodes:

# Bad: Too complex in one expression
count = floor(sqrt(max(0, min($area, 1000)) / $density)) * 2 + $base

# Better: Use intermediate parameters
area_clamped = min($area, 1000)
base_count = floor(sqrt(area_clamped / $density))
count = base_count * 2 + $base

docs.title: Avoid Division by Zero
docs.text:
# Risky
result = $numerator / $denominator

# Safe
result = $denominator != 0 ? $numerator / $denominator : 0
result = $numerator / max($denominator, 0.0001)

docs.title: Use Descriptive Names
docs.text:
# Bad
$x, $y, $temp, $val

# Good
$tower_height, $wall_thickness, $door_count

docs.title: Comment Complex Logic
docs.text: While Nodo doesn't support comments in expressions, use graph parameter descriptions to document complex calculations.

docs.title: Common Errors
docs.text:
"Syntax error" - Check parentheses are balanced: (()) ✓ (() ✗ - Check comma placement in functions: max(a, b) ✓ max(a b) ✗ - Check quotes for strings: "text" ✓ text ✗

"Unknown function" - Function name misspelled: sqrt ✓ squareroot ✗ - Function doesn't exist: check Math Functions

"Type mismatch" - Can't mix incompatible types: 5 + "hello" ✗ - Use type conversion: str(5) + "hello" ✓

"Reference not found" - Parameter doesn't exist: check spelling - Path is wrong: use correct ch() path - Graph parameter not created yet

docs.title: Debugging Expressions
docs.text:
Test in isolation: 1. Create a simple test parameter 2. Enter just the problematic part 3. Build up complexity gradually

Use intermediate calculations: 1. Break expression into steps 2. Create separate parameters for each step 3. Verify each step works

Check types: - Ensure numbers are numbers (not strings) - Verify boolean logic returns 0 or 1 - Use str() to debug: str($value) shows what value actually is

docs.title: Current Limitations
docs.text:
• No custom functions - Can't define your own functions
  • No loops - Can't iterate (use Array nodes instead)
  • No arrays - Can't create lists (use multiple parameters)
  • No external data - Can't read files or fetch data
  • No state - Expressions are stateless (same input = same output)

docs.text:
Planned for future versions:

  • Animation support ($F will work)
  • User-defined functions
  • Vector/array operations
  • Noise functions (Perlin, Simplex)

docs.title: Efficient Expressions
docs.text:
Fast: 

$value * 2
$value + 10
abs($value)

Slower: 

pow($value, 2.5)  # Use when needed
sin($value * 360)

Avoid Redundant Calculations: 

# Bad: Calculates sqrt twice
result1 = sqrt($a * $b) + 10
result2 = sqrt($a * $b) * 2

# Better: Use graph parameter for sqrt($a * $b)
$temp = sqrt($a * $b)
result1 = $temp + 10
result2 = $temp * 2

+  -  *  /  %  ^         # Arithmetic

docs.title: Graph Parameters
docs.text: Graph Parameters are reusable controls that can drive multiple nodes in your network. They're the foundation of parametric, data-driven modeling in Nodo.

docs.title: What are Graph Parameters?
docs.text:
Graph Parameters let you:

  • Define once, use everywhere - Create a parameter that controls multiple nodes
  • Build intelligent models - Make your procedural systems respond to high-level controls
  • Create presets - Save different parameter sets for quick iterations
  • Share controls - Let one slider affect many operations

Think of them as "master controls" for your node graph.

docs.title: Using the Graph Parameters Panel
docs.text:
1. Open Graph Parameters panel (View → Panels → Graph Parameters)
  2. Click the "+" button (Add Parameter) in the toolbar
  3. Enter parameter details:
  4. Name: Unique identifier (e.g., base_radius, tower_height)
  5. Type: Float, Int, Bool, String, or Vector3
  6. Default Value: Initial value
  7. Range (for numeric types): Min and max values
  8. Click OK

The parameter now appears in the Graph Parameters panel and can be referenced in expressions.

Edit or Delete

  • Double-click a parameter to edit it
  • Select and click "-" to delete (warns if in use)

docs.title: Referencing in Expressions
docs.text:
Once created, reference graph parameters in any expression:

$param_name

Or using the full path:

ch("/graph/param_name")

docs.title: Example: Controlled Scale
docs.text:
Setup: 1. Create graph parameter: scale_factor (Float, default 1.0) 2. Add a Sphere node 3. Set Sphere's radius expression: $scale_factor 4. Add a Box node 5. Set Box's size_x expression: $scale_factor * 2

Now one slider controls both shapes!

docs.title: Float
docs.text:
Decimal numbers with optional range.

Properties: - Default value - Min/Max range - UI widget: Slider or number field

Example: 

Name: detail_level
Type: Float
Default: 1.0
Range: 0.1 to 5.0

Usage: 

ch("/graph/detail_level") * 32  # Scale segments based on detail

docs.title: Int
docs.text:
Whole numbers.

Properties: - Default value - Min/Max range - UI widget: Number field or slider

Example: 

Name: copy_count
Type: Int
Default: 6
Range: 1 to 100

Usage: 

$copy_count  # Direct use in Array count

docs.title: Bool
docs.text:
True/false toggle.

Properties: - Default value (on/off) - UI widget: Checkbox

Example: 

Name: enable_detail
Type: Bool
Default: true

Usage: 

$enable_detail ? 64 : 16  # Conditional segments

docs.title: String
docs.text:
Text values.

Properties: - Default text - UI widget: Text field

Example: 

Name: export_prefix
Type: String
Default: "model"

Usage: 

$export_prefix + "_v01.obj"  # Build file paths

docs.title: Vector (Vec3)
docs.text:
Three float values (X, Y, Z).

Properties: - Default X, Y, Z - Optional range per component - UI widget: Three number fields

Example: 

Name: global_offset
Type: Vec3
Default: (0, 0, 0)

Usage: 

ch("/graph/global_offset.x")  # Access X component
ch("/graph/global_offset.y")  # Access Y component

docs.title: Simple Reference
docs.text: $radius  # Use graph parameter directly

docs.title: Math with Parameters
docs.text:
$base_size * 2.5  # Scale up
sin($angle) * $amplitude  # Trigonometry

docs.title: Combining Multiple Parameters
docs.text:
$width * $height * $depth  # Volume calculation
min($max_size, $input_value)  # Clamping

docs.title: Conditional Logic
docs.text: $enable_feature ? $detail_high : $detail_low

docs.title: Vector Components
docs.text:
ch("/graph/offset.x") + 10  # Offset X by 10
length(ch("/graph/position"))  # Vector magnitude

docs.title: Master Scale Control
docs.text:
Create a single scale parameter that affects everything:

  1. Graph parameter: master_scale (Float, default 1.0)
  2. All size-related parameters use: base_value * $master_scale

Example: - Sphere radius: 1.0 * $master_scale - Box size: 2.0 * $master_scale - Array spacing: 3.0 * $master_scale

docs.title: Detail Level System
docs.text:
Control model complexity with one slider:

  1. Graph parameter: detail (Float, 0.0 to 1.0)
  2. Use for subdivision, segments, etc.

Example: 

segments = int(8 + $detail * 56)  # 8 to 64 segments
subdivisions = floor($detail * 3)  # 0 to 3 subdivisions

docs.title: Feature Toggles
docs.text:
Enable/disable parts of your model:

  1. Graph parameter: include_details (Bool, default true)
  2. Use in Switch nodes or conditionals

Example: 

$include_details ? 1 : 0  # Switch node input selection

docs.title: Export Variants
docs.text:
Drive multiple export configurations:

  1. Graph parameters: lod_level (Int), export_name (String)
  2. Use in Export node paths and settings

docs.title: Naming Conventions
docs.text:
Use Clear Names

  • ✅ tower_height, wall_thickness, door_count
  • ❌ var1, temp, x

Group Related Parameters

Use prefixes: tower_height, tower_radius, tower_segments

docs.title: Organize Parameters
docs.text: Group by purpose: - Global: master_scale, detail_level - Dimensions: width, height, depth - Features: enable_windows, enable_roof - Export: export_format, export_quality

docs.title: Set Sensible Ranges
docs.text:
Always Set Ranges

Unbounded parameters can cause issues: - Set realistic min/max values - Prevents accidental extreme values - Improves UI (sliders work better)

Example: 

height: 0.1 to 100.0  # Building height in meters
segments: 3 to 128    # Geometry detail

docs.title: Document Your Parameters
docs.text:
Use descriptions to explain what each parameter controls:

Name: wall_thickness
Type: Float
Range: 0.05 to 2.0
Description: "Thickness of outer walls in meters"

docs.title: Derived Parameters
docs.text:
Create parameters that calculate from others:

# Graph parameter: base_radius
# Another node uses:
diameter = $base_radius * 2
circumference = $base_radius * 2 * pi

docs.title: Ratio-Based Design
docs.text:
Lock proportions using ratios:

# Graph parameter: base_width
height = $base_width * 1.618  # Golden ratio
depth = $base_width * 0.5     # Half width

docs.title: Responsive Systems
docs.text:
Make geometry adapt to changes:

# More copies = smaller size (maintain total coverage)
copy_size = $total_size / $copy_count

docs.title: Multi-Stage Control
docs.text:
Chain parameters through multiple nodes:

1. Graph param: complexity (0-1)
2. Node A: segments = 8 + $complexity * 56
3. Node B: subdivisions = floor($complexity * 3)
4. Node C: scatter_count = int(100 + $complexity * 900)

docs.title: Panel Features
docs.text:
• Add Parameter - Create new graph parameter
  • Edit Parameter - Change name, type, range, default
  • Delete Parameter - Remove unused parameters
  • Reorder - Drag to organize

docs.title: Editing Parameters
docs.text: Click a parameter to edit: - Name - Identifier used in expressions - Label - Display name in UI - Type - Float, Int, Bool, String, Vec3 - Default - Initial value - Range - Min/max bounds (for numeric types) - Description - Tooltip help text

docs.title: "Parameter not found" error
docs.text:
Cause: Parameter name misspelled or doesn't exist.

Fix: - Check spelling: $radius vs $raduis - Verify parameter exists in Graph Parameters panel - Use exact name (case-sensitive)

docs.title: Expression doesn't update
docs.text:
Cause: Parameter reference is wrong, or expression is cached.

Fix: - Click parameter to refresh - Check expression syntax - Try re-entering the expression

docs.title: Parameter has no effect
docs.text:
Cause: No nodes are using the parameter.

Fix: - Reference it in node parameter expressions: $param_name - Verify expressions are in Expression Mode (blue)

docs.title: Can't delete graph parameter
docs.text:
Cause: Parameter is still referenced by nodes.

Fix: - Find all references (future: show usage count) - Remove references first - Then delete the parameter

docs.title: Architectural Column
docs.text:
Create a parametric column:

Graph Parameters: 

height: 3.0 (Float, 0.5 to 20.0)
radius: 0.3 (Float, 0.1 to 2.0)
flutes: 12 (Int, 4 to 32)

Node Setup: 1. Cylinder (height: $height, radius: $radius) 2. Array Radial (count: $flutes) 3. Boolean Subtract (create fluting)

docs.title: Procedural Building
docs.text:
Graph Parameters: 

floors: 5 (Int, 1 to 50)
floor_height: 3.0 (Float, 2.5 to 5.0)
width: 10.0 (Float, 5.0 to 50.0)

Expressions: 

building_height = $floors * $floor_height
window_spacing = $floor_height * 0.8

docs.title: Export Variants
docs.text:
Graph Parameters: 

lod: 1 (Int, 0 to 3)  # Level of detail
export_name: "asset" (String)

Expressions: 

segments = 8 * pow(2, $lod)  # 8, 16, 32, 64
filename = $export_name + "_lod" + str($lod) + ".obj"

docs.title: Math Functions
docs.text: Complete reference for mathematical functions available in Nodo expressions.

docs.title: abs
docs.text:
abs(x)
Returns the absolute value of x.

Examples: 

abs(-5)     → 5
abs(3.2)    → 3.2
abs(0)      → 0

docs.title: sqrt
docs.text:
sqrt(x)
Returns the square root of x.

Examples: 

sqrt(16)    → 4
sqrt(2)     → 1.414...
sqrt(0)     → 0

docs.title: pow
docs.text:
pow(base, exponent)
Returns base raised to the power of exponent.

Examples: 

pow(2, 8)   → 256
pow(10, 3)  → 1000
pow(4, 0.5) → 2 (square root)

docs.title: exp
docs.text:
exp(x)
Returns e^x (Euler's number raised to x).

Examples: 

exp(0)      → 1
exp(1)      → 2.71828...
exp(2)      → 7.38906...

docs.title: log
docs.text:
log(x)         # Natural logarithm (base e)
log10(x)       # Base 10 logarithm

Examples: 

log(2.71828)   → 1
log10(100)     → 2
log10(1000)    → 3

docs.title: floor
docs.text:
floor(x)
Rounds down to nearest integer.

Examples: 

floor(3.7)  → 3
floor(3.2)  → 3
floor(-2.5) → -3

docs.title: ceil
docs.text:
ceil(x)
Rounds up to nearest integer.

Examples: 

ceil(3.2)   → 4
ceil(3.7)   → 4
ceil(-2.5)  → -2

docs.title: round
docs.text:
round(x)
Rounds to nearest integer.

Examples: 

round(3.4)  → 3
round(3.5)  → 4
round(3.6)  → 4

docs.title: trunc
docs.text:
trunc(x)
Removes decimal part (rounds toward zero).

Examples: 

trunc(3.7)  → 3
trunc(-3.7) → -3

docs.title: min
docs.text:
min(a, b)
min(a, b, c, ...)
Returns the smallest value.

Examples: 

min(5, 10)      → 5
min(3, 1, 7)    → 1
min(-2, 0, 5)   → -2

docs.title: max
docs.text:
max(a, b)
max(a, b, c, ...)
Returns the largest value.

Examples: 

max(5, 10)      → 10
max(3, 1, 7)    → 7
max(-2, 0, 5)   → 5

docs.title: clamp
docs.text:
clamp(value, min, max)
Constrains value between min and max.

Examples: 

clamp(15, 0, 10)    → 10
clamp(-5, 0, 10)    → 0
clamp(5, 0, 10)     → 5

docs.title: Trigonometry (Degrees)
docs.text: All trigonometric functions use degrees, not radians.

docs.title: sin
docs.text:
sin(degrees)
Sine function.

Examples: 

sin(0)      → 0
sin(30)     → 0.5
sin(90)     → 1
sin(180)    → 0

docs.title: cos
docs.text:
cos(degrees)
Cosine function.

Examples: 

cos(0)      → 1
cos(60)     → 0.5
cos(90)     → 0
cos(180)    → -1

docs.title: tan
docs.text:
tan(degrees)
Tangent function.

Examples: 

tan(0)      → 0
tan(45)     → 1
tan(90)     → undefined (very large)

docs.title: asin
docs.text:
asin(value)
Arc sine (inverse sine), returns degrees.

Examples: 

asin(0)     → 0
asin(0.5)   → 30
asin(1)     → 90

docs.title: acos
docs.text:
acos(value)
Arc cosine (inverse cosine), returns degrees.

Examples: 

acos(1)     → 0
acos(0.5)   → 60
acos(0)     → 90

docs.title: atan
docs.text:
atan(value)
Arc tangent (inverse tangent), returns degrees.

Examples: 

atan(0)     → 0
atan(1)     → 45
atan(-1)    → -45

docs.title: atan2
docs.text:
atan2(y, x)
Two-argument arc tangent (handles quadrants correctly).

Examples: 

atan2(1, 1)     → 45
atan2(1, -1)    → 135
atan2(-1, -1)   → -135

docs.title: lerp
docs.text:
lerp(a, b, t)
Linear interpolation from a to b by factor t (0 to 1).

Examples: 

lerp(0, 10, 0.5)    → 5
lerp(0, 10, 0)      → 0
lerp(0, 10, 1)      → 10
lerp(100, 200, 0.25) → 125

docs.title: smoothstep
docs.text:
smoothstep(edge0, edge1, x)
Smooth hermite interpolation (ease in/out).

Examples: 

smoothstep(0, 1, 0.5)   → 0.5 (but smoother curve)
smoothstep(0, 10, 3)    → ~0.3

Returns 0 if x ≤ edge0, 1 if x ≥ edge1, smooth interpolation between.

docs.title: mod / %
docs.text:
mod(a, b)
a % b
Modulo (remainder after division).

Examples: 

10 % 3      → 1
7 % 2       → 1
15 % 5      → 0

docs.title: sign
docs.text:
sign(x)
Returns sign of x: -1, 0, or 1.

Examples: 

sign(10)    → 1
sign(-5)    → -1
sign(0)     → 0

docs.title: fract
docs.text:
fract(x)
Returns fractional part of x (x - floor(x)).

Examples: 

fract(3.7)      → 0.7
fract(5.2)      → 0.2
fract(-2.3)     → 0.7

docs.title: fmod
docs.text:
fmod(x, y)
Floating-point remainder.

Examples: 

fmod(5.5, 2.0)  → 1.5
fmod(7.2, 3.0)  → 1.2

docs.title: PI
docs.text:
$PI or pi()
Pi constant (3.14159265359...).

Examples: 

$PI * 2         → 6.283... (2π)
sin($PI / 2)    → 1 (but use sin(90))

docs.title: E
docs.text:
$E
Euler's number (2.71828...).

Examples: 

$E              → 2.71828...
pow($E, 2)      → 7.389... (e²)

docs.title: int
docs.text:
int(x)
Converts to integer (truncates decimals).

Examples: 

int(3.7)        → 3
int(3.2)        → 3
int("42")       → 42

docs.title: float
docs.text:
float(x)
Converts to floating-point number.

Examples: 

float(42)       → 42.0
float("3.14")   → 3.14

docs.title: bool
docs.text:
bool(x)
Converts to boolean (0 = false, non-zero = true).

Examples: 

bool(0)         → false
bool(1)         → true
bool(0.1)       → true

docs.title: str
docs.text:
str(x)
Converts to string.

Examples: 

str(42)         → "42"
str(3.14)       → "3.14"
str(true)       → "true"

docs.title: length
docs.text:
length(vector)
Returns magnitude of vector.

Examples: 

length(vec3(3, 4, 0))   → 5
length(vec3(1, 0, 0))   → 1

docs.title: normalize
docs.text:
normalize(vector)
Returns unit vector (length = 1).

Examples: 

normalize(vec3(3, 4, 0))    → vec3(0.6, 0.8, 0)
normalize(vec3(10, 0, 0))   → vec3(1, 0, 0)

docs.title: dot
docs.text:
dot(vec1, vec2)
Dot product of two vectors.

Examples: 

dot(vec3(1,0,0), vec3(0,1,0))   → 0 (perpendicular)
dot(vec3(1,0,0), vec3(1,0,0))   → 1 (parallel)

docs.title: cross
docs.text:
cross(vec1, vec2)
Cross product of two vectors.

Examples: 

cross(vec3(1,0,0), vec3(0,1,0)) → vec3(0,0,1)

docs.title: distance
docs.text:
distance(vec1, vec2)
Distance between two points.

Examples: 

distance(vec3(0,0,0), vec3(3,4,0))  → 5

docs.title: Circular Arrangement
docs.text:
# Position on circle
x = cos($index * 360 / $count) * $radius
z = sin($index * 360 / $count) * $radius

docs.title: Damped Oscillation
docs.text:
# Sine wave with decay
amplitude = exp(-$index / 10) * $base_amp
offset = sin($index * 36) * amplitude

docs.title: Responsive Scaling
docs.text:
# Scale based on input range
normalized = ($value - $min) / ($max - $min)
scaled = $out_min + normalized * ($out_max - $out_min)

docs.title: Grid Snapping
docs.text:
# Snap to nearest grid point
snapped_x = round($x / $grid_size) * $grid_size
snapped_y = round($y / $grid_size) * $grid_size

docs.title: Falloff
docs.text:
# Distance-based falloff
distance_ratio = distance($point, $center) / $max_distance
falloff = 1.0 - clamp(distance_ratio, 0, 1)
smooth_falloff = smoothstep(0, 1, falloff)

docs.title: Alternating Pattern
docs.text:
# Switch between two values
value = $index % 2 == 0 ? $value_a : $value_b

docs.text:

  • Channel References - Referencing parameters
  • Graph Parameters - Creating reusable parameters

Pro Tip: Combine functions for complex effects: 

offset = smoothstep(0, 1, fract($index / 10)) * sin($index * 36) * $amplitude

docs.text:

  • CPU: Dual-core processor (2 GHz+)
  • RAM: 4 GB
  • GPU: OpenGL 3.3 compatible graphics card
  • Storage: 200 MB free space
