docs.text:
• OS: Windows 11 or Linux (Ubuntu 22.04+)
  • CPU: Quad-core processor (3 GHz+)
  • RAM: 8 GB or more
  • GPU: Dedicated graphics card with 2 GB VRAM
  • Storage: 500 MB free space

docs.title: Download Nodo
docs.text:
Download the latest version from the official website: nodo3d.com

Choose your platform: - Windows: Nodo-Windows-x64.zip - Linux: Nodo-Linux-x64.AppImage

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
1. Download the Windows ZIP file
  2. Extract to a folder (e.g., C:\Program Files\Nodo)
  3. Run nodo_studio.exe
  4. Optional: Create a desktop shortcut

Windows Defender

Windows may show a SmartScreen warning for unsigned applications. Click "More info" → "Run anyway".

docs.title: Linux
docs.text:
1. Download the AppImage file
  2. Make it executable: 
    chmod +x Nodo-Linux-x64.AppImage
  3. Run the AppImage: 
    ./Nodo-Linux-x64.AppImage

Desktop Integration

Most Linux systems will prompt to integrate the AppImage into your application menu.

docs.title: Interface Overview
docs.text: Learn your way around the Nodo interface. This guide explains each panel and how they work together.

docs.title: Main Window Layout
docs.text:
The Nodo interface has four main areas:

  1. Menu Bar (top) - File operations, edit commands, view options
  2. Node Graph (center-bottom) - Visual programming workspace
  3. Viewport (center-top) - 3D geometry preview
  4. Side Panels (left & right) - Node library and properties

docs.title: File Menu
docs.text:
• New Scene (Ctrl+N) - Start fresh project
  • Open Scene (Ctrl+O) - Load existing .nfg file
  • Recent Projects - Quick access to recent files
  • Save Scene (Ctrl+S) - Save current project
  • Save Scene As (Ctrl+Shift+S) - Save with new name
  • Exit - Close Nodo

docs.title: Edit Menu
docs.text:
• Undo (Ctrl+Z) - Reverse last action
  • Redo (Ctrl+Shift+Z) - Reapply undone action
  • Copy (Ctrl+C) - Copy selected nodes to clipboard
  • Paste (Ctrl+V) - Paste copied nodes (with 50px offset)
  • Duplicate (Ctrl+D) - Duplicate selected nodes with connections
  • Delete (Del) - Remove selected nodes
  • Select All (A) - Select all nodes in graph
  • Deselect All (Shift+A) - Clear selection
  • Invert Selection (Ctrl+I) - Invert current selection

docs.title: View Menu
docs.text:
Display toggles for the viewport:

  • Show Vertices - Display geometry points
  • Show Edges - Display edge wireframe
  • Show Vertex Normals (N) - Normal vector arrows at vertices
  • Show Face Normals (Shift+N) - Normal vector arrows at face centers
  • Show Grid (G) - Ground plane grid
  • Show Axes - XYZ axis indicator
  • Toggle Wireframe (W) - Wireframe display mode

Panels:

  • Graph Parameters Panel - Show/hide graph parameters controls
  • Property Panel - Show/hide node properties panel

docs.title: Help Menu
docs.text:
• Documentation (F1) - Opens this documentation site
  • Keyboard Shortcuts (Ctrl+/) - Quick reference guide
  • About Nodo - Version and credits

docs.title: Node Graph Panel
docs.text: The heart of Nodo - where you build procedural workflows.

docs.title: Nodes
docs.text:
Each node has:

  • Title Bar - Node name (double-click to rename)
  • Input Pins (left) - Accept geometry from other nodes
  • Output Pins (right) - Send geometry to other nodes
  • Body - Shows node type and category

docs.text:
• Selected - Orange highlight, parameters shown in Property Panel
  • Error - Red indicator (hover to see error message)
  • Disabled - Grayed out (not evaluated)

docs.title: Connections
docs.text:
Creating Connections: 1. Click and drag from an output pin 2. Release on an input pin 3. A curved line appears

Connection Colors: - Gray - Default, inactive - Blue - Hovered (ready to select) - Orange - Selected

Deleting Connections: - Single-click to select, press Del - Right-click → Delete Connection

docs.text:
Right-click in the node graph:

  • Add Node - Quick node creation menu
  • Paste - Paste copied nodes
  • Select All - Select all nodes (Ctrl+A)
  • Deselect All - Clear selection

Right-click on a node:

  • Duplicate (Ctrl+D) - Copy the node with connections
  • Delete (Del) - Remove the node
  • Bypass (B) - Toggle bypass (node passes input through unchanged)
  • Disconnect All (Shift+D) - Remove all connections to/from node

Right-click on a connection:

  • Delete Connection - Remove the link

docs.title: Viewport Panel
docs.text: 3D preview of your geometry in real-time.

docs.title: Viewport Toolbar
docs.text: Located at the top of the viewport:

docs.title: Display Toggles (Left Side)
docs.text:
• ● Vertices - Show/hide vertex points
  • ─ Edges - Show/hide edge lines
  • ↑V Vertex Normals - Display vertex normal arrows
  • ↑F Face Normals - Display face normal arrows

docs.title: Shading Modes
docs.text:
Wireframe Mode: - Shows only edges - Good for dense geometry - Toggle with wireframe button

Shaded Mode: - Solid surfaces with lighting - Shows geometry shape - Default mode

Combined Mode: - Both wireframe and shading - Toggle both buttons on

docs.title: Node Library Panel
docs.text: Find and add nodes to your graph.

docs.title: Organization
docs.text:
Nodes are organized by category:

  • 📦 Generator (6 nodes) - Create geometry primitives
  • 🔧 Modifier (16 nodes) - Transform and deform geometry
  • 📋 Array (4 nodes) - Duplicate and distribute
  • ⚡ Boolean (2 nodes) - Combine geometries
  • 📊 Attribute (5 nodes) - Manage geometry data
  • 👥 Group (6 nodes) - Selection and masking
  • 💾 IO (2 nodes) - Import/export files
  • ⚙️ Utility (7 nodes) - Helper nodes

docs.title: Using the Node Library
docs.text:
1. Expand a category by clicking it
  2. Click a node to add it to the graph
  3. The node appears at the graph center

Search Feature (Coming Soon)

Future versions will include node search for quick access.

docs.title: Graph Parameters Panel
docs.text:
Control multiple nodes with shared parameters.

The Graph Parameters panel (View → Panels → Graph Parameters) lets you create master controls that drive multiple nodes at once.

docs.title: Creating Graph Parameters
docs.text:
1. Click the + button in the panel toolbar
  2. Enter parameter details:
  3. Name: Unique identifier (e.g., base_scale, detail_level)
  4. Type: Float, Int, Bool, String, or Vector3
  5. Value: Initial value
  6. Range (optional): Min/max for numeric types
  7. Click OK

docs.title: Using Graph Parameters
docs.text:
Reference graph parameters in any node parameter using expressions:

$param_name                   # Direct reference
$base_scale * 2              # With math
ch("/graph/param_name")      # Explicit path

Example Workflow: 1. Create graph parameter: master_size (Float, default 1.0) 2. In Sphere node, set radius: $master_size 3. In Box node, set size: $master_size * 2 4. Now one slider controls both shapes!

docs.title: Your First Model: A Simple Tower
docs.text: Let's create a procedural tower using basic nodes. This tutorial introduces core concepts while building something interesting.

docs.title: Add a Box Node
docs.text:
1. Open the Node Library panel (left side of the screen)
  2. Expand the Generator category
  3. Click Box to add it to the graph
  4. The box appears in both the viewport and node graph

docs.title: Adjust the Base Dimensions
docs.text:
1. Select the Box node in the node graph (click it)
  2. The Property Panel appears on the right
  3. Under the Size category, set:
  4. Size X: 2.0
  5. Size Y: 0.5 (shorter in Y for a platform)
  6. Size Z: 2.0

You should now see a flat platform in the viewport!

Quick Parameter Entry

Click a parameter value and type directly. Press Enter to confirm or Tab to move to the next parameter.

docs.title: Step 2: Add a Cylinder for the Tower
Create a Cylinder
docs.text:
1. From Node Library → Generator, click Cylinder
  2. A new cylinder appears in the viewport

docs.title: Position It Above the Base
docs.text:
1. Select the Cylinder node
  2. In the Node Library, find Modifier → Transform and click it
  3. A Transform node appears in the graph

docs.title: Connect the Nodes
docs.text:
1. Click and drag from the Cylinder's output pin (right side)
  2. Drop on the Transform's input pin (left side)
  3. A connection line appears

docs.title: Move the Cylinder Up
docs.text:
1. Select the Transform node
  2. In the Property Panel, under Transform:
  3. Translate Y: 2.0 (moves it up)
  4. The cylinder now sits above the base!

Node Connections

Data flows left to right. The Transform node takes the Cylinder's geometry and moves it.

docs.title: Add a Merge Node
docs.text:
1. From Node Library → Boolean, click Merge
  2. This node combines multiple geometries

docs.title: Connect Both Pieces
docs.text:
1. Drag from the Box output to Merge input 0
  2. Drag from the Transform output to Merge input 1

The viewport now shows both pieces together!

Multiple Inputs

Merge nodes can accept many inputs. Each input adds more geometry to the combined result.

docs.title: Step 4: Add Detail with an Array
Create Pillars Around the Tower
docs.text:
1. Select the Cylinder node (before Transform)
  2. Add an Array node (from Array category)
  3. Insert it between Cylinder and Transform:
  4. Remove the Cylinder → Transform connection (right-click → Delete Connection)
  5. Connect: Cylinder → Array → Transform

docs.title: Configure the Array
docs.text:
1. Select the Array node
  2. In the Property Panel:
  3. Type: Select Radial from dropdown
  4. Count: 6 (creates 6 copies)
  5. Radius: 2.5 (distance from center)

Now you have 6 pillars arranged in a circle!

docs.title: Adjust Pillar Size
docs.text:
1. Select the Cylinder node
  2. Adjust parameters:
  3. Radius: 0.15 (thinner pillars)
  4. Height: 3.0 (taller)

docs.title: Create a Cone
docs.text:
1. Add another Cylinder node
  2. In its Property Panel:
  3. Primitive Type: Cone
  4. Radius Bottom: 2.5
  5. Radius Top: 0.1
  6. Height: 1.5

docs.title: Position It on Top
docs.text:
1. Add a Transform node
  2. Connect: Cone Cylinder → Transform
  3. Set Translate Y: 4.5

docs.title: Add to the Merge
docs.text:
1. Connect the roof's Transform → Merge
  2. Your tower is complete!

docs.title: Node Reference
docs.text: Complete reference for all 40 nodes in Nodo (Alpha Preview - November 2025).

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Nodes are organized into 8 categories. Each node performs a specific operation on geometry and can be connected to create procedural workflows.

Legend: - ✅ Fully implemented and tested - ⚠️ Basic implementation (limited features) - 🚧 Placeholder (Phase 2)

docs.title: Generator (6 nodes)
docs.text:
Create primitive geometry shapes.

  • Box ✅ - Create a box primitive
  • Cylinder ✅ - Create a cylinder primitive
  • Grid ✅ - Create a planar grid of polygons
  • Line ✅ - Create a line or curve
  • Sphere ✅ - Create a UV sphere or icosphere
  • Torus ✅ - Create a torus primitive

docs.title: Modifier (5 nodes)
docs.text:
Transform and modify geometry.

  • Extrude ✅ - Extrude geometry along normals
  • Subdivide ✅ - Subdivide polygons for smoother geometry
  • Smooth (Laplacian) ✅ - Smooth geometry using Laplacian method
  • Noise Displacement ✅ - Displace geometry using noise
  • Bevel ⚠️ - Create beveled edges (basic, 1 segment only)

docs.title: Transform (6 nodes)
docs.text:
Position, duplicate, and arrange geometry.

  • Transform ✅ - Translate, rotate, scale geometry
  • Array ✅ - Create linear or grid arrays
  • Copy to Points ✅ - Copy geometry to point positions
  • Mirror ✅ - Mirror geometry across a plane
  • Scatter ✅ - Scatter points across geometry surface
  • Scatter Volume ✅ - Scatter points within bounding volume
  • Align ✅ - Align geometry bounding box to axes or origin

docs.title: Boolean & Combine (5 nodes)
docs.text:
Merge and combine meshes.

  • Boolean ✅ - Union, subtract, intersect operations
  • Merge ✅ - Merge multiple geometries into one
  • Split ✅ - Separate geometry by connectivity or attribute
  • PolyExtrude ✅ - Extrude individual polygons
  • Remesh 🚧 - Uniform mesh triangulation (stub only)

docs.title: Attribute (6 nodes)
docs.text:
Manage geometry data and attributes.

  • Wrangle ✅ - VEX-like scripting for attributes
  • Attribute Create ✅ - Create or modify attributes
  • Attribute Delete ✅ - Delete attributes from geometry
  • Color ✅ - Set vertex colors
  • Normal ✅ - Compute or modify vertex/face normals
  • UV Unwrap ✅ - Generate UV coordinates (xatlas)

docs.title: Group (7 nodes)
docs.text:
Select and organize geometry components.

  • Group ✅ - Create geometry groups (bounds, normal, random)
  • Blast ✅ - Delete geometry by group
  • Sort ✅ - Sort points or primitives
  • Group Promote ✅ - Convert groups between component types
  • Group Combine ✅ - Boolean operations on groups
  • Group Expand ✅ - Grow/shrink group selection
  • Group Transfer ✅ - Transfer groups between geometries

docs.title: Deformers (3 nodes)
docs.text:
Non-destructive deformations.

  • Bend ✅ - Bend geometry along an axis
  • Twist ✅ - Twist geometry around an axis
  • Lattice ✅ - Deform geometry with a lattice cage

docs.title: Utility (5 nodes)
docs.text:
Workflow helpers and I/O.

  • Switch ✅ - Choose between multiple inputs
  • Null ✅ - Pass-through node for organization
  • Output ✅ - Mark geometry as final output
  • File ✅ - Import geometry from OBJ/STL files
  • Export ✅ - Export geometry to OBJ format

docs.title: Future Nodes (Phase 2+)
docs.text:
The following nodes are planned for future releases:

  • Cache - Freeze expensive operations
  • Time - Animation timeline control
  • Resample - Resample curves with uniform spacing
  • Full Bevel - Multi-segment beveling with profile control
  • Full Remesh - Intelligent remeshing algorithms

docs.text:

            ┌→ [Export] (low_poly.obj)

            └→ [Export] (high_poly.obj)

docs.title: Export Settings
docs.text: The OBJ exporter uses the following conventions: - Coordinate system: Y-up, right-handed - Units: Preserves scene units (typically meters) - Face orientation: Counter-clockwise winding - Normals: Exported as vertex normals if present

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text: Error Message Cause Solution "No input geometry" Input not connected Connect geometry to input "No file path specified" File Path is empty (warning) Enter a valid file path "Failed to write file" Permission error or invalid path Check folder exists and is writable

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• The node only exports when Export Now is clicked, not on every evaluation
  • If File Path is empty, the node acts as a simple pass-through
  • Use absolute paths or paths relative to the project file
  • The parent directory must exist - create folders first
  • Files are overwritten without warning - version your exports if needed

docs.title: Attributes Preserved
docs.text:
The Export node preserves all standard attributes: - @P - Position (always exported) - @N - Normals (exported if present) - @Cd - Vertex colors (exported if present) - @uv - UV coordinates (exported if present)

Custom attributes are not currently exported to OBJ but may be supported in future formats.

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: Common questions and answers about Nodo.

docs.title: What is Nodo?
docs.text: Nodo is a procedural 3D modeling application that uses node-based workflows. Instead of manually pushing vertices, you create geometry by connecting nodes that perform operations (create shapes, transform, combine, etc.).

docs.title: Who is Nodo for?
docs.text:
• 3D Artists - Create procedural models for games, film, architecture
  • Game Developers - Build modular, parameterized assets
  • Technical Artists - Automate repetitive modeling tasks
  • Designers - Explore variations quickly with parametric controls
  • 3D Print Enthusiasts - Generate customizable designs

docs.title: Is Nodo free?
docs.text: Nodo is commercial software. Check the official website for pricing and licensing options.

docs.title: What platforms does Nodo support?
docs.text:
• Windows 10/11 (64-bit)
  • Linux Ubuntu 20.04+ and compatible distributions

macOS is not currently supported.

docs.title: Where do I download Nodo?
docs.text: Download from the official website: nodo3d.com

docs.title: What are the system requirements?
docs.text:
Minimum: - Dual-core CPU (2 GHz+) - 4 GB RAM - OpenGL 3.3+ graphics card

Recommended: - Quad-core CPU (3 GHz+) - 8 GB+ RAM - Dedicated GPU with 2 GB VRAM

See Installation Guide for details.

docs.title: I get "Failed to initialize OpenGL" error
docs.text:
Your graphics card or drivers don't support OpenGL 3.3+.

Solutions: - Update your graphics drivers to the latest version - Check if your GPU supports OpenGL 3.3 (released 2010) - For Intel integrated graphics, ensure drivers are up to date

docs.title: Nodo crashes on startup (Windows)
docs.text:
You may be missing Visual C++ Runtime libraries.

Solution: Download and install Visual C++ Redistributable

docs.title: The viewport is blank/black
docs.text: Possible causes: 1. No geometry is created yet - Add a node from the Generator category 2. Camera needs adjustment - Press A to frame all geometry 3. All nodes have errors - Check for red error indicators 4. Display toggles are off - Check viewport toolbar buttons

docs.title: Where are my settings/projects saved?
docs.text:
Windows: %APPDATA%/Nodo/NodoStudio/ Linux: ~/.config/Nodo/NodoStudio/

Recent files list and UI preferences are stored here.

docs.title: How do I add a node?
docs.text:
1. Open Node Library panel (left side)
  2. Expand a category (Generator, Modifier, etc.)
  3. Click a node to add it to the graph

Or use the context menu: Right-click in node graph → Add Node

docs.title: How do I connect nodes?
docs.text:
1. Click and drag from an output pin (right side of node)
  2. Release on an input pin (left side of another node)

A curved line appears showing the connection.

docs.title: How do I delete a node?
docs.text:
Select the node and press Del or Backspace.

Or right-click → Delete.

docs.title: How do I delete a connection?
docs.text:
• Single-click the connection to select it, then press Del
  • Right-click the connection → Delete Connection

docs.title: How do I duplicate a node?
docs.text:
Select the node and press Ctrl+D.

Or right-click → Duplicate.

docs.title: Can I copy/paste nodes?
docs.text:
Yes! - Copy: Ctrl+C - Paste: Ctrl+V - Cut: Ctrl+X

Works across different scenes too.

docs.title: What do the node colors mean?
docs.text:
• Green indicator - Node is valid, no errors
  • Red indicator - Node has an error (hover to see message)
  • Yellow indicator - Warning (non-critical issue)
  • Orange highlight - Node is selected

docs.title: My node has a red error indicator
docs.text:
Hover over the error indicator to see the error message. Common causes:

  • Missing required input connections
  • Invalid parameter values (e.g., radius = 0)
  • Geometry operation failed (e.g., invalid boolean)

docs.title: How do I rename a node?
docs.text: Double-click the node's title bar and type a new name.

docs.title: How do I edit a parameter?
docs.text:
1. Select a node in the graph
  2. The Property Panel (right side) shows its parameters
  3. Click a value to edit, or drag to scrub

docs.title: What is Expression Mode?
docs.text:
Expression Mode lets you use math formulas instead of fixed values.

Enable it: - Click the ≡ button next to the parameter - Button changes to # and a text field appears - Type your expression and press Enter

The parameter turns blue when the expression is valid.

docs.title: What can I write in expressions?
docs.text:
Basic math: 

2 + 2
sin(45) * 2
max(10, 20)

Reference other parameters: 

ch("../other_node/radius")
ch("radius") * 2

See Expression Syntax for full reference.

docs.title: How do I reference another parameter?
docs.text:
Use ch("path/to/parameter"):

ch("../sphere/radius")      # Reference sibling node's radius
ch("../../control")         # Reference parent's parameter

docs.title: What math functions are available?
docs.text:
Trigonometry: sin, cos, tan, asin, acos, atan Math: sqrt, pow, abs, min, max, floor, ceil, round Utility: clamp, lerp, smoothstep

See Math Functions for complete list.

docs.title: Can I animate parameters?
docs.text:
Not yet. Animation support (timeline, keyframes) is planned for a future version.

The $F variable (frame number) exists in expressions but currently always returns 0.

docs.title: How do I navigate the viewport?
docs.text: Action Control Rotate Middle Button drag or Alt+Left Button Pan Shift+Middle Button or Shift+Alt+Left Button Zoom ++scroll-wheel++ or Alt+Right Button

docs.title: How do I frame my geometry?
docs.text:
• A or Home - Frame all geometry
  • F - Frame selected node's output

Or use the Fit View button in viewport toolbar.

docs.title: How do I toggle wireframe?
docs.text:
Click the Wireframe button in the viewport toolbar (top-right).

You can have both wireframe and shading on at the same time.

docs.title: What are the viewport display toggles?
docs.text:
In the viewport toolbar:

  • ● Vertices - Show geometry points
  • ─ Edges - Show edge wireframe
  • ↑V Vertex Normals - Display normal arrows
  • ↑F Face Normals - Display face normals
  • # Point Numbers - Number each vertex
  • ⊕ Grid - Show ground grid

docs.title: The viewport is slow/laggy
docs.text:
For complex geometry:

  1. Turn off Vertex Normals and Face Normals (expensive to draw)
  2. Use Wireframe mode instead of shaded
  3. Hide the Grid if not needed
  4. Consider using a Cache node to freeze expensive operations

docs.title: What file format does Nodo use?
docs.text:
Nodo uses .nfg (Nodo Graph) files to save your node networks.

This is a JSON-based format that stores: - All nodes and their parameters - Connections between nodes - Graph parameter definitions - UI layout preferences

docs.title: How do I save my work?
docs.text:
File → Save Scene (Ctrl+S)

Choose a location and filename. The .nfg extension is added automatically.

docs.title: Can I export geometry?
docs.text:
Yes! Use an Export node (IO category):

  1. Add Export node to graph
  2. Connect geometry to it
  3. Select the Export node
  4. Set File Path and Format
  5. The geometry is exported when the node evaluates

docs.title: What export formats are supported?
docs.text:
• OBJ - Wavefront OBJ (widely compatible)
  • STL - Stereolithography (3D printing)
  • PLY - Polygon File Format (supports vertex colors)
  • glTF - GL Transmission Format (modern, with materials)

docs.title: Can I import geometry?
docs.text:
Yes! Use a File node (IO category):

  1. Add File node to graph
  2. Set File Path to your model file
  3. Supported formats: OBJ, STL, PLY, glTF, OFF

The imported geometry can be modified with other nodes.

docs.title: Where are recent files shown?
docs.text:
File → Recent Projects shows the last 10 opened .nfg files.

Click one to quickly reopen it.

docs.title: Undo doesn't work / History is lost
docs.text:
Undo/Redo is fully supported for: - Adding/deleting nodes - Changing parameters - Creating/deleting connections

If undo seems broken: - Make sure you're using Ctrl+Z - Check if the action is undoable (file operations aren't)

docs.title: Parameter changes don't update the viewport
docs.text:
The graph should auto-update. If it doesn't:

  1. Check if the node has an error indicator
  2. Ensure nodes are connected to an Output node (or visible node)
  3. Try selecting a different node and back

If the issue persists, try reloading the scene.

docs.title: Boolean operations fail
docs.text:
Boolean operations (Union, Subtract, Intersect) require:

  • Manifold geometry - No holes, self-intersections, or non-closed surfaces
  • Valid input - Both inputs must be solid geometry

Common fixes: - Use Merge instead if you just want to combine meshes - Check input geometry for errors - Try simplifying geometry before boolean

docs.title: Nodes won't connect
docs.text: Check that: - You're dragging from output pin (right side) to input pin (left side) - The target node accepts that input type - The target input pin isn't already connected (disconnect first)

docs.title: Copy to Points isn't working
docs.text: Ensure: - Input 0 has points/geometry to copy TO - Input 1 has the geometry to BE copied - Point positions exist in input 0

docs.title: Expression shows error
docs.text:
Common expression errors:

  • Syntax error - Check parentheses, commas, quotes
  • Unknown function - Function name misspelled
  • Invalid reference - ch() path is wrong
  • Type mismatch - Trying to use string in math operation

Hover the parameter to see the error message.

docs.title: How do I make Nodo faster?
docs.text:
1. Use Cache nodes - Freeze expensive operations
  2. Reduce geometry complexity - Lower subdivision/resolution on generators
  3. Disable viewport features - Turn off normals, point numbers
  4. Use Switch nodes - Disable branches you're not working on

docs.title: What's the geometry limit?
docs.text:
There's no hard limit, but performance depends on your hardware.

General guidelines: - < 100k vertices - Real-time editing on most systems - 100k - 1M vertices - May lag on complex operations - > 1M vertices - Consider using Cache nodes, or work in pieces

docs.title: Does Nodo use GPU acceleration?
docs.text:
Currently, geometry operations run on CPU. The viewport uses GPU for rendering.

GPU-accelerated geometry operations are planned for future versions.

docs.title: Architectural Modeling Workflow
docs.text: Learn to create procedural buildings with adjustable parameters - perfect for architectural visualization, game levels, and city generation.

docs.title: Project Goal
docs.text:
Build a parametric office building with: - Adjustable height and floor count - Automatic window placement - Entrance area - Roof cap - Full control via graph parameters

Time: 45-60 minutes

docs.title: Step 1: Base Building Volume
docs.text:
1. Add Box node (Tab → "box")
  2. Size X: 10
  3. Size Y: 30 (initial height)

  4. Size Z: 10

  5. Add Transform node

  6. Connect: Box → Transform
  7. Translate Y: 15 (lift base to ground)

Why Transform?

Keeps the building base at Y=0 (ground level), making it easier to work with.

docs.title: Step 2: Create Graph Parameters
docs.text:
Open View → Panels → Graph Parameters, add:

Name Type Default Min Max Description building_width Float 10.0 5.0 50.0 Building width (X/Z) building_height Float 30.0 10.0 200.0 Total height floor_count Int 10 3 50 Number of floors floor_height Float 3.0 2.5 4.0 Height per floor

docs.title: Step 3: Link Parameters to Base
docs.text:
Update Box node: - Click ≡ button next to Size X → Expression mode - Size X: $building_width - Size Y: $floor_count * $floor_height - Size Z: $building_width

Update Transform node: - Translate Y: $building_height / 2

Test: Change $floor_count from 10 to 20 → Building doubles in height!

docs.title: Step 4: Create Window Recess
docs.text:
1. Add Grid node
  2. Segments X: 1
  3. Segments Z: 1
  4. Size X: 0.8

  5. Size Z: 0.6

  6. Add Extrude node

  7. Connect: Grid → Extrude
  8. Distance: -0.2 (extrude inward)

This creates a single window recess.

docs.title: Step 5: Array Windows Horizontally
docs.text:
1. Add Array node
  2. Connect: Extrude → Array
  3. Mode: Linear
  4. Count: Click ≡ → floor($building_width / 2.5)
  5. Offset X: 2.5
  6. Offset Y: 0
  7. Offset Z: 0

Result: Windows space evenly along building width.

docs.title: Step 6: Array Windows Vertically
docs.text:
1. Add Array node (second one)
  2. Connect: Array_1 → Array_2
  3. Mode: Linear
  4. Count: $floor_count
  5. Offset X: 0
  6. Offset Y: $floor_height
  7. Offset Z: 0

Result: Windows on every floor!

docs.title: Step 7: Position Window Grid
docs.text:
1. Add Transform node
  2. Connect: Array_2 → Transform
  3. Translate X: $building_width / 2 + 0.1 (position on front face)
  4. Translate Y: $floor_height / 2 (center on first floor)
  5. Translate Z: 0
  6. Rotate Y: 0 (front face)

docs.title: Step 8: Subtract Windows from Building
docs.text:
1. Add Boolean node
  2. Input A: Transform_1 (the building base)
  3. Input B: Transform_2 (the window array)
  4. Operation: Subtract

Result: Windows cut into building facade!

Boolean Order Matters

A subtract B ≠ B subtract A

Building - Windows = Building with holes ✅ Windows - Building = Just windows ❌

docs.title: Step 9: Add Windows to All Sides
docs.text:
For back/left/right facades, we need 3 more window arrays.

Quick method: 1. Select Transform_2 node (the window positioning) 2. Ctrl + D to duplicate 3. Rename to "windows_back" 4. Rotate Y: 180 (face opposite direction)

Repeat for left (Rotate Y: 90) and right (Rotate Y: -90).

Update Boolean: - Connect all 4 window arrays to Input B (multiple connections allowed) - Or use multiple Boolean nodes in sequence

docs.title: Step 10: Create Entrance Door
docs.text:
1. Add Box node
  2. Size X: 2.0
  3. Size Y: 3.0

  4. Size Z: 0.3

  5. Add Transform node

  6. Connect: Box → Transform
  7. Translate X: $building_width / 2 + 0.05
  8. Translate Y: 1.5
  9. Translate Z: 0

docs.title: Step 11: Entrance Overhang
docs.text:
1. Add Box node
  2. Size X: 3.0
  3. Size Y: 0.3

  4. Size Z: 1.5

  5. Add Transform node

  6. Translate X: $building_width / 2
  7. Translate Y: 3.2
  8. Translate Z: 0

docs.title: Step 12: Combine Entrance Elements
docs.text:
1. Add Merge node
  2. Connect: Door Transform → Merge
  3. Connect: Overhang Transform → Merge
  4. Connect: Merge → Boolean (Input B, for subtraction)

Result: Door hole with overhang!

docs.title: Step 13: Roof Cap
docs.text:
1. Add Box node
  2. Size X: $building_width + 0.5
  3. Size Y: 1.0

  4. Size Z: $building_width + 0.5

  5. Add Transform node

  6. Translate Y: $building_height + 0.5

  7. Add Boolean or Merge node

  8. Combine roof with main building
  9. Use Merge for separate piece, Boolean Union for solid

docs.title: Step 14: Add Ground Plane
docs.text:
1. Add Grid node
  2. Size X: 50
  3. Size Z: 50

  4. Segments: 1

  5. Add Transform node

  6. Translate Y: 0 (at ground level)

  7. Merge with building

docs.title: Step 15: Material Zones
docs.text:
Optional: Add material IDs for multi-material export.

  1. Add Group node after building
  2. Expression: @P.y < 1.0

  3. Group: "ground_floor"

  4. Add Attribute Create node

  5. Name: materialid
  6. Type: Int
  7. Value: @ground_floor ? 2 : 1

Result: Ground floor gets material ID 2, upper floors ID 1.

docs.title: Step 16: Add Window Variations
docs.text:
Create graph parameter:

Name Type Default Description window_spacing Float 2.5 Space between windows window_width Float 0.8 Window width window_depth Float 0.2 Window recess depth

Update window Grid: - Size X: $window_width

Update window Array: - Offset X: $window_spacing

Now: Adjust window density globally!

docs.title: Step 17: Add Balconies (Optional)
docs.text:
1. Add Box → balcony platform
  2. Array → every 3rd floor: floor(@id / ($floor_count / 3))
  3. Merge with building

docs.title: Step 18: Final Assembly
docs.text:
Organize your graph:

[Base Structure] → [Window Subtraction] → [Entrance] → [Roof] → [Final Merge]

Name all nodes for clarity: - "base_volume" - "window_grid_front" - "entrance_door" - "roof_cap" - etc.

docs.title: Test Parameter Ranges
docs.text:
Try extreme values:

  • $floor_count = 3 → Short building
  • $floor_count = 50 → Skyscraper
  • $building_width = 5 → Narrow tower
  • $building_width = 40 → Wide complex

Check: - Windows still align properly? - Entrance proportional? - Roof caps correctly?

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Windows overlap: - Increase $window_spacing - Or link to $building_width / $window_count

Building too short/tall: - Ensure Size Y = $floor_count * $floor_height

Boolean fails: - Check both inputs are manifold (closed meshes) - Simplify geometry if too complex

docs.title: Level of Detail (LOD)
docs.text:
Add graph parameter $detail_level:

Window segments = $detail_level > 0.5 ? 8 : 4
Boolean quality = $detail_level

Low detail for preview, high for final render.

docs.title: Randomization
docs.text:
Add variety with random seed:

Window offset noise:
ch("../window_array/offset_x") + rand($random_seed + @id) * 0.1

docs.title: Modular System
docs.text:
Create variations:

  • Base graph: Core building
  • Duplicate & modify: Different window styles
  • Switch via parameter: Modern vs Classic

docs.title: Export OBJ
docs.text:
1. File → Export → OBJ
  2. Choose location
  3. Options:
  4. ✅ Export normals
  5. ✅ Export material IDs (if created)

docs.title: Import to Blender/Unity/Unreal
docs.text:
• OBJ imports as static mesh
  • Material IDs map to material slots
  • Ready for texturing and lighting

docs.title: Game Level Generation
docs.text: Workflow: 1. Create base building graph 2. Duplicate with variations (height, width, style) 3. Export multiple buildings 4. Scatter in game engine 5. Result: Unique city blocks!

docs.text:
After completing this tutorial, you can:

✅ Create parametric buildings with graph parameters ✅ Use arrays for window distribution ✅ Perform boolean operations for cutouts ✅ Build multi-part models with merge nodes ✅ Add variation through expressions ✅ Export for external use

docs.text:
Your final graph should have:

$building_height = 30.0   (total height)

docs.title: Game Assets Workflow
docs.text: Create optimized, game-ready 3D assets with LOD (Level of Detail) variants and clean topology - perfect for Unity, Unreal Engine, or custom game engines.

docs.title: Project Goal
docs.text:
Build a procedural crate asset with: - Clean, game-ready topology - Multiple LOD levels - Configurable detail parameters - Optimized poly count - Export-ready geometry

Time: 30-40 minutes

docs.title: Step 1: Setup Graph Parameters
docs.text:
Create control parameters first:

Name Type Default Min Max Description crate_size Float 1.0 0.5 3.0 Crate dimensions detail_level Float 0.5 0.0 1.0 LOD control (0=low, 1=high) plank_inset Float 0.05 0.0 0.2 Wood plank depth corner_bevel Float 0.02 0.0 0.1 Edge rounding

docs.title: Step 2: Create Base Box
docs.text:
1. Add Box node
  2. Size X: $crate_size
  3. Size Y: $crate_size
  4. Size Z: $crate_size
  5. Center: ✅ Enabled

Result: 1×1×1 meter cube (12 triangles - very low poly!)

docs.title: Step 3: Add Wood Plank Details
docs.text:
Create planks on each face:

  1. Add Grid node
  2. Segments X: 1
  3. Segments Z: Click ≡ → ceil($detail_level * 5 + 1)
  4. Size X: $crate_size - 0.1

  5. Size Z: $crate_size - 0.1

  6. Add Transform node (for positioning)

  7. Translate X: $crate_size / 2 + 0.01
  8. Translate Y: 0
  9. Translate Z: 0

This creates plank lines on one face.

docs.title: Step 4: Duplicate for All 6 Faces
docs.text:
Quick approach: Use Array with rotation

  1. Add Array node
  2. Mode: Radial
  3. Count: 4
  4. Axis: Y
  5. Angle: 90 (degrees)

Creates planks on 4 sides.

  1. Manually add top and bottom planks (rotate 90° on X axis)

Or use Transform nodes for precise control.

docs.title: Step 5: LOD0 (High Detail)
docs.text:
When $detail_level >= 0.7:

  1. Add Subdivide node (conditional)
  2. Connect: Box → Subdivide

  3. Subdivisions: Click ≡ → $detail_level > 0.7 ? 1 : 0

  4. Add Bevel (if available) or Smooth

  5. Amount: $corner_bevel

Poly count: ~200-500 triangles

docs.title: Step 6: LOD1 (Medium Detail)
docs.text:
When $detail_level 0.3-0.7:

  • Base box with plank lines
  • No subdivision
  • Minimal beveling

Poly count: ~50-100 triangles

docs.title: Step 7: LOD2 (Low Detail)
docs.text:
When $detail_level < 0.3:

  • Just the base box
  • No plank details
  • Sharp edges

Poly count: 12 triangles

docs.title: Step 8: Automatic LOD Switching
docs.text:
Use conditional merging:

Base Box
  ↓
[Detail Level Check]
  ↓ if $detail_level > 0.3
Add Plank Details
  ↓ if $detail_level > 0.7
Add Subdivision + Bevel

Expression example: 

Plank count = $detail_level > 0.3 ? 5 : 0

docs.title: Step 9: Add Damage/Wear (Optional)
docs.text:
Create dent geometry:

  1. Add Sphere (small)

  2. Radius: 0.1

  3. Add Scatter node

  4. Target: Crate surface
  5. Count: Click ≡ → $detail_level > 0.5 ? 5 : 0

  6. Random seed: 42

  7. Add Boolean (Subtract)

  8. Crate - Dents = Damaged crate

Result: Procedural wear marks (only at high detail!)

docs.title: Step 10: Metal Corner Brackets
docs.text:
1. Add Box (thin, corner piece)
  2. Size X: 0.05
  3. Size Y: $crate_size * 0.3

  4. Size Z: 0.05

  5. Add Array (8 corners)

  6. Position at corners using Transform

  7. Merge with crate

Poly budget: ~20 triangles per bracket × 8 = 160 tris

docs.title: Step 11: Clean Geometry
docs.text:
Critical for game engines:

  1. Check manifold status:
  2. All edges have exactly 2 faces
  3. No holes or gaps

  4. Proper normals

  5. Weld vertices:

  6. Use Merge node with weld enabled

  7. Threshold: 0.001

  8. Remove interior faces:

  9. Group (select internal geometry)
  10. Group Delete

docs.title: Step 12: Poly Count Targets
docs.text:
Game industry standards:

LOD Level Poly Count Usage LOD0 (High) 500-2000 tris Close-up view (< 5m) LOD1 (Med) 100-500 tris Medium distance (5-20m) LOD2 (Low) 12-100 tris Far distance (> 20m)

Your crate: - LOD0: ~500 tris (detailed planks, bevels) - LOD1: ~100 tris (plank lines only) - LOD2: ~12 tris (just box)

docs.title: Step 13: UV Coordinates
docs.text:
For texturing:

  1. Check if UVs exist:
  2. Some generators create UVs automatically

  3. Box, Grid usually include basic UVs

  4. Simple box mapping:

  5. Each face gets 0-1 UV space
  6. Good enough for tiling textures

Advanced: UV unwrapping (future Nodo feature)

docs.title: Step 14: Create Material IDs
docs.text:
For multi-material export:

  1. Add Group node
  2. Expression: @P.y > $crate_size / 2 - 0.05

  3. Group: "metal_brackets"

  4. Add Attribute Create node

  5. Name: materialid
  6. Type: Int
  7. Value: @metal_brackets ? 2 : 1

Result: - Material 1 = Wood planks - Material 2 = Metal brackets

docs.title: Step 15: Vertex Colors (Optional)
docs.text:
For vertex-color shading:

Attribute Create:
  Name: Cd
  Type: Vector3
  Value: [0.6, 0.4, 0.2]  # Wood brown color

Variation: 

Random tint per vertex:
  Cd: [0.6 + rand(@id) * 0.1, 0.4, 0.2]

docs.title: Step 16: Export OBJ/FBX
docs.text:
For Unity/Unreal:

  1. File → Export → OBJ
  2. Options:
  3. ✅ Export normals (for lighting)
  4. ✅ Export UVs (for textures)
  5. ✅ Export material IDs (if multi-mat)

  6. ❌ Flip Y-axis (depends on engine)

  7. Filename convention: 

    crate_LOD0.obj  (high detail)
crate_LOD1.obj  (medium)
crate_LOD2.obj  (low)

docs.title: Step 17: Import to Game Engine
docs.text:
Unity: 1. Drag OBJ into Assets 2. Set LOD Group component 3. Assign LOD0, LOD1, LOD2 meshes 4. Set distance thresholds: LOD0 (0-10m), LOD1 (10-30m), LOD2 (30m+)

Unreal: 1. Import as Static Mesh 2. LOD Settings → Import LOD levels 3. Auto-generate collisions

docs.title: Crate Variants from One Graph
docs.text:
Create multiple crates:

Change $crate_size: - Small: 0.5 → Pickup item - Medium: 1.0 → Standard prop - Large: 2.0 → Shipping container

docs.title: Procedural Patterns Workflow
docs.text: Master the art of creating repeating patterns, tilings, and textures procedurally - essential for architectural details, decorative elements, and surface treatments.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Learn to create: - Geometric patterns (grids, hexagons, radial) - Organic variations (randomness, noise-based) - Tiling systems (seamless repetition) - 3D surface patterns (relief, embossing)

Time: 30-45 minutes per pattern type

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Create a realistic brick pattern with offset rows and mortar gaps.

docs.title: Step 1: Single Brick
docs.text:
1. Add Box node
  2. Size X: 0.2 (brick length)
  3. Size Y: 0.1 (brick height)
  4. Size Z: 0.05 (brick depth)

docs.title: Step 2: Horizontal Row
docs.text:
1. Add Array node
  2. Mode: Linear
  3. Count: 10
  4. Offset X: 0.21 (brick + mortar gap)
  5. Offset Y: 0
  6. Offset Z: 0

Result: Row of 10 bricks with gaps.

docs.title: Step 3: Vertical Stacking
docs.text:
1. Add Array node (second one)
  2. Mode: Linear
  3. Count: 8
  4. Offset X: 0
  5. Offset Y: 0.11 (brick height + mortar)
  6. Offset Z: 0

Result: 8 rows stacked vertically.

docs.title: Step 4: Running Bond Pattern
docs.text:
Create offset on alternating rows:

  1. Add Attribute Create node (before vertical array)
  2. Name: row_offset
  3. Type: Float

  4. Value: Click ≡ → floor(@id / 10) % 2 * 0.105

  5. Add Transform node

  6. Translate X: Click ≡ → @row_offset

Result: Classic brick pattern with offset rows!

docs.title: Step 5: Add Variation
docs.text:
Randomize brick colors:

  1. Add Attribute Create node
  2. Name: Cd
  3. Type: Vector3
  4. Value: [0.6 + rand(@id) * 0.15, 0.3 + rand(@id+100) * 0.1, 0.2]

Result: Subtle color variation per brick.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Create honeycomb/hex tile pattern.

docs.title: Step 1: Single Hexagon
docs.text:
1. Add Cylinder node
  2. Radius: 0.5
  3. Height: 0.1
  4. Segments: 6 (hexagon!)
  5. Cap: ✅ Top and bottom

docs.title: Step 2: Horizontal Row
docs.text:
1. Add Array node
  2. Mode: Linear
  3. Count: 8
  4. Offset X: 1.5 (1.5 × radius for tight packing)
  5. Offset Y: 0

docs.title: Step 3: Offset Second Row
docs.text:
Hexagons pack with offset:

  1. Duplicate the array (Ctrl+D)
  2. Add Transform node
  3. Translate X: 0.75 (half offset)
  4. Translate Z: 0.866 (√3/2 × radius for vertical spacing)

docs.title: Step 4: Stack Rows
docs.text:
1. Merge the two arrays
  2. Add Array node (vertical)
  3. Count: 6
  4. Offset Z: 1.732 (√3 × radius)

Result: Perfect hexagonal tiling!

docs.title: Step 5: Add Grout Lines
docs.text:
Create gaps between tiles:

  1. Add Transform node (before merge)
  2. Scale: 0.95 (shrink each tile 5%)

Result: Gaps appear as grout/mortar.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Create circular/mandala-like pattern.

docs.title: Step 1: Petal/Segment
docs.text:
1. Add Box node
  2. Size X: 0.2
  3. Size Y: 1.0

  4. Size Z: 0.1

  5. Add Transform node

  6. Translate Y: 0.5 (offset from center)

docs.title: Step 2: Radial Array
docs.text:
1. Add Array node
  2. Mode: Radial
  3. Count: Click ≡ → $petal_count (create graph param, default 12)
  4. Axis: Z (perpendicular to pattern)
  5. Angle: 360 degrees

Result: Flower-like radial pattern!

docs.title: Step 3: Add Inner Ring
docs.text:
1. Duplicate array
  2. Add Transform node
  3. Scale: 0.5

  4. Rotate Z: 15 degrees (offset from outer ring)

  5. Merge with outer ring

docs.title: Step 4: Center Detail
docs.text:
1. Add Cylinder node
  2. Radius: 0.3

  3. Height: 0.1

  4. Merge with pattern

Result: Multi-layer radial design!

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Create 3D checkerboard with raised tiles.

docs.title: Step 1: Base Grid
docs.text:
1. Add Grid node
  2. Segments X: 8
  3. Segments Z: 8
  4. Size X: 8
  5. Size Z: 8

docs.title: Step 2: Select Alternating Tiles
docs.text:
1. Add Group node
  2. Mode: Expression
  3. Expression: (floor(@P.x + 4) + floor(@P.z + 4)) % 2 == 0
  4. Group: "white_tiles"

docs.title: Step 3: Extrude White Tiles
docs.text:
1. Add Extrude node (if operates on groups)
  2. Distance: 0.2

Or create two separate grids (white raised, black flat) and merge.

docs.title: Step 4: Add Colors
docs.text:
1. Add Attribute Create node
  2. Name: Cd
  3. Type: Vector3
  4. Value: @white_tiles ? [0.9, 0.9, 0.9] : [0.1, 0.1, 0.1]

Result: 3D checkerboard pattern!

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Natural-looking scattered elements (pebbles, grass clumps).

docs.title: Step 1: Base Surface
docs.text:
1. Add Grid node
  2. Segments X: 20
  3. Segments Z: 20
  4. Size: 10 × 10

docs.title: Step 2: Create Element to Scatter
docs.text:
1. Add Sphere node (or any object)
  2. Radius: Click ≡ → 0.1 + rand($seed) * 0.05

docs.title: Step 3: Scatter on Surface
docs.text:
1. Add Scatter node
  2. Input A: Grid (surface)
  3. Input B: Sphere (object to scatter)
  4. Count: Click ≡ → $scatter_density (graph param, default 100)
  5. Random Seed: $seed

docs.title: Step 4: Add Variation
docs.text:
Randomize scale and rotation:

  1. Add Attribute Create node (on scattered instances)
  2. Name: scale_var

  3. Value: 0.8 + rand(@id) * 0.4

  4. Add Transform node

  5. Scale: Click ≡ → @scale_var
  6. Rotate Z: rand(@id + 1000) * 360

Result: Natural-looking distribution with variation!

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Sinusoidal wave pattern on surface.

docs.title: Step 1: Base Grid
docs.text:
1. Add Grid node
  2. Segments X: 50
  3. Segments Z: 50
  4. Size: 10 × 10

docs.title: Step 2: Apply Wave Deformation
docs.text:
Displace vertices using sine function:

  1. Add Attribute Create node
  2. Name: wave_height
  3. Type: Float

  4. Value: sin(@P.x * $frequency) * $amplitude

  5. Add Transform or displacement (future feature)

Current workaround: Use expression for Y position: 

Create new position attribute:
@new_y = @P.y + sin(@P.x * 2.0) * 0.5

docs.title: Step 3: Add Second Wave (Perpendicular)
docs.text:
@wave = sin(@P.x * $freq_x) * sin(@P.z * $freq_z) * $amplitude

Result: Ripple/interference pattern!

docs.title: Step 4: Color by Height
docs.text:
1. Add Attribute Create node
  2. Name: Cd
  3. Value: [0, @P.y + 0.5, 1 - @P.y]

Result: Blue-to-white gradient wave!

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Organic cell-like divisions (future feature, manual approach).

docs.title: Current Approach: Scatter + Regions
docs.text:
1. Add Grid (dense)

  2. Segments: 100 × 100

  3. Scatter points (seeds)

  4. Count: 20

  5. Attribute Create (distance to nearest seed)

  6. Requires custom logic (future feature)

Simpler alternative: Use radial gradients from scattered points.

docs.title: Seamless Tiling
docs.text:
For repeating patterns:

  1. Ensure dimensions match:
  2. Pattern width = exact multiple of unit size

  3. Pattern height = exact multiple of unit size

  4. Wrap-around offsets: 

    X offset at edge = X offset at start
(modulo pattern width)

  5. Test tiling:

  6. Array the pattern
  7. Check for visible seams

docs.title: Combining Patterns
docs.text:
Layer multiple patterns:

Base pattern (large scale)
  ↓ Merge
Detail pattern (small scale)
  ↓ Boolean (subtract for cutouts)
Final composite

docs.title: Parametric Control
docs.text:
Create graph parameters:

$pattern_scale = 1.0     (overall size)
$pattern_density = 8     (repetitions)
$variation_seed = 42     (randomness)
$detail_level = 0.5      (complexity)

Link all pattern parameters to these globals.
